revision.text:
'''Baloz''' or '''bajloz''' is a sea monster in [[Albanian mythology]].
==Etymology== [[Maximilian Lambertz]] suggested that the word derived from Italian ''[[bailo]]'', the title of the [[Republic of Venice|Venetian]] ambassador to the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomans]].<ref name=Elsie>{{cite book|author1=Robert Elsie|author2=Janice Mathie-Heck|title=Songs of the Frontier Warriors|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5xgxBY81S7IC&pg=PA367|year=2004|publisher=Bolchazy-Carducci Publishers|isbn=978-0-86516-412-3|pages=367–}}</ref>
Literally, the word seems to have originated from the [[Albanian language|Albanian]] ''blozë''(soot), referring to baloz's armour color, or maybe from [[Turkish language|Turkish]] word "balyoz" meaning "hammer", maybe due to the hammers of war the baloz carried.{{cn|date=February 2017}}
==Folklore== Baloz (as a character) has been found in many Albanian myths and legends about fighting against the Albanian nobles such as: Muji, Halili, [[Gjergj Elez Alia]] and [[Constantin and Doruntinë|Constantin]]. The monster is found in the [[Albanian Songs of the Frontier Warriors]].<ref name=Elsie/>
Detailed descriptions have been found in a collection of Albanian myths named ''Ancient Albanian Tales'' ({{lang-sq|Tregime të Moçme Shqiptare}})<ref>{{cite book |title=Tregime të moçme shqiptare |last=Kuteli |first=Mitrush |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1987 |publisher=Naim Frasheri |location=Tirana |isbn= |page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=10rhAAAAMAAJ&q=P%C3%ABrralla+t%C3%AB+Mo%C3%A7me+Shqiptare&dq=P%C3%ABrralla+t%C3%AB+Mo%C3%A7me+Shqiptare&hl=en&ei=eyQ2TNnWI8T68AbGw5GDDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&resnum=2&ved=0CC0Q6wEwAQ |accessdate=2010-07-08 }}</ref> collected and rewritten by [[Dhimitër Pasko]].
'''Baloz Sedelija''' was a Slavic warrior in Albanian folklore.<ref name=Elsie/> Another character was '''Baloz(i) i Zi'''.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Albania-stub}} [[Category:Albanian folklore]] [[Category:Albanian legendary creatures]]

revision.comment: added information about Bini's short feature movie
revision.text:
{{unreliable sources|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox animal | name = Bini the Bunny | image =Bini and his art.jpg | image_upright = | caption = Bini and some of his paintings. | species = ''[[Domestic Rabbit]]'' | breed = [[Holland Lop]] | gender = Male | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|2012|3|21|mf=yes}} | occupation = | employer = | role = | years_active = 2012–present | known = [[Internet Celebrity]] | tricks = Basketball, Painting, Hair Styling | awards = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | owner = [[Shai Lighter]] | residence = Los Angeles, California U.S. | parents = Unknown | children = | weight = 5 lbs | height = | appearance = | namedafter = | website = {{url|http://www.facebook.com/Binithebunny}} }} '''Bini the Bunny''' is a rabbit, known for a series of videos posted on the internet.<ref>{{cite web | title=Bini, basketball's baddest bunny | website=[[Ynet]] | date=December 31, 1999 | url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4485656,00.html | accessdate=February 12, 2017}}</ref> Bini is a 6-year-old male [[Holland Lop]] rabbit, referred to by the media and fans as the only bunny in the world who can paint,<ref>{{cite web|title=Talented Little Bunny Creates Beautiful Works Of Art, All On His Own!|url=http://www.jumblejoy.com/artist-bunny|website=Jumble Joy|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> play basketball,<ref>{{cite web | last=Schwartz | first=Nick | title=Here's a bunny that can dunk a basketball | publisher=[[CNN]] | date=June 11, 2013 | url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2013/06/heres-a-bunny-that-can-dunk-a-basketball | accessdate=February 12, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Meet Bini, The Basketball-Dunking Bunny|url=http://www.thepostgame.com/blog/animal-house/201306/meet-bini-basketball-dunking-bunny|website=The Post Game|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> and comb and style hair. As of 2017, Bini and his owner, Shai (Asor) Lighter are [[Guinness World Records|Guinness Book of World Record]] holders for the most slam dunks by a rabbit in one minute. Bini's most popular video with over 20 million views was created in 2016, titled "When Your Bunny is Addicted to Arcade Games".<ref>{{cite web|title=When your bunny is addicted to arcade games...|url=https://www.facebook.com/binithebunny/videos/705862269561334/|website=Facebook.com|publisher=Bini the Bunny}}</ref> Bini's YouTube channel has more than 140,000 subscribers and his Facebook page has over 250,000 fans.
== Background == Bini has starred in more than 60 videos where his talents and intelligence are exemplified. He first became recognizable through his 2013 YouTube video "Funny bunny plays basketball -Bini the bunny".<ref>{{cite web|title=Funny bunny plays basketball -Bini the bunny|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r7mC6Q-PSAw|website=Youtube|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref> In 2016, Bini moved to Los Angeles, California,<ref>{{cite web|title=Bini is moving to Hollywood (for real)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pl9QKSCibmY|website=Youtube|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> where his owner Shai Lighter sought to further build his brand and gain increased exposure for him.
Bini the Bunny's tricks include playing basketball, painting<ref>{{cite web|title=Monday blues? This PAINTING RABBIT will cheer you right up|url=http://www.shemazing.net/tag/bini-the-bunny/|website=Shemazing.net|accessdate=15 February 2017}}</ref> with acrylic paints on canvas, combing and brushing humans' hair, jumping, dancing and spinning on command.
== Awards ==
Bini the Bunny was recognized and awarded a record by [[Guinness World Records]] for most slam dunks by a rabbit in 60 seconds. Bini broke the record in October 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title= The 2018 Guinness Book of World Records, in pictures|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/09/07/2018-guinness-book-world-records-pictures/bini-bunny-has-record-slam-dunks-rabbit/}}</ref>.
In 2017, the Facebook page for Bini the Bunny was recognized as "official" by Facebook. Bini has more than 200,000 Facebook fans.<ref>{{cite web|title=Facebook Bini the Bunny|url=https://www.facebook.com/binithebunny/|website=Facebook.com|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref>
In 2018, YouTube awarded Bini and Shai the Silver Creator Award for reaching and passing 100,000 subscribers. <ref>{{cite web|title=Bini Silver Award|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VJJsTPvIFxU&feature=youtu.be|website=Youtube}}</ref>
== Media appearances ==
Bini the Bunny and Shai Lighter appeared on [[The Gong Show]] on ABC on July 26, 2018. <ref>{{cite web|title=The Gong Show|url=https://abc.go.com/shows/the-gong-show/episode-guide/season-02/6-alyson-hannigan-will-arnett-lil-rel-howery#recap|accessdate=8 August 2018}}</ref>The Gong Show starring [[Mike Myers]], and featured celebrity judges: Will Arnett, [[Alyson Hannigan]], and Lil Rel Howery
Bini was featured on the cover of Guinness World Records: Amazing Animals released in September 2017 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/products/books/amazing-animals-2018|title=Amazing Animals}}</ref>
His tricks have been documented on video on various media outlets, and he has been featured in articles by ''Huffington Post'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Bini The Bunny Plays Basketball Like A Pro|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/10/bini-the-bunny-plays-basketball-like-a-pro_n_3417391.html|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=11 February 2017}}</ref> AOL,<ref>{{cite web|title=Bini The Bunny Plays Basketball|url=http://www.aol.co.uk/video/bini-the-bunny-plays-basketball-517813168/|website=AOL UK|accessdate=15 February 2017}}</ref> ''USA Today'', ''Fox News'', and Sky News, among others. In 2016, Bini the Bunny was featured on LittleThings.com by Jessica Rothhaar<ref>{{cite web|title=Bini The Bunny Plays Basketball And Paints Works Of Art|url=https://www.littlethings.com/bini-the-bunny-paints/|website=Little Things|accessdate=1 November 2016}}</ref> and on German TV Network RTL Germany on the variety show ''Best Of'' . In July 2017, Bini the Bunny and Shai Lighter were featured on the UK Channel E4 [[Rude Tube]] show, Season 11, Episode 9<ref>{{cite web|title=Bini on UK Channel E4 - Rude Tube|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZgcJdINRI1Y&feature=youtu.be|website=Youtube}}</ref>
In 2018, Bini was invited to the Red Carpet Premiere for the Peter Rabbit movie as a "celebrity rabbit".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/james-corden-peter-rabbit-premiere-1202686674|title=Red Carpet|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}}</ref>
On September 27, 2018, Bini the Bunny's first short-feature film was released to the world, titled '''Rabbit Home Alone''' which features Shai Lighter, and an array of actors as well as Bin<ref>{{Citation|last=Bini the Bunny|title=Rabbit Home Alone (full version) - Home Alone Parody|date=2018-09-27|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0j8Gt5JQPKc|access-date=2018-09-29}}</ref>i. The movie is a parody of 1990 feature film [[Home Alone]].
== References == {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite web | title=Conheça Bini the Bunny: o coelhinho pintor e jogador de basquete | website=[[Correio Braziliense]] | date=August 22, 2016 | url=http://www.correiobraziliense.com.br/app/noticia/mundo/2016/08/22/interna_mundo,545377/conheca-bini-the-bunny-o-coelhinho-pintor-e-jogador-de-basquete.shtml | language=pt | ref=harv | accessdate=February 12, 2017}} * {{cite web | title=Rencontre avec Bini, le lapinou le plus génial de toute la planète! | website=Le Tribunal Du Net | date=August 25, 2016 | url=http://www.letribunaldunet.fr/animaux/bini-le-lapin-qui-sait-tout-faire.html | language=fr | ref={{sfnref | Le Tribunal Du Net | 2016}} | accessdate=February 12, 2017}} * {{cite web | last=Smart | first=Tasha | title=Bini the Bunny combs his owner's hair using a comb in his mouth | website=Capital Bay News | date=June 20, 2016 | url=http://www.capitalbay.news/female/1049991-bini-the-bunny-combs-his-owner-s-hair-using-a-comb-in-his-mouth.html | ref=harv | accessdate=February 12, 2017}} * {{cite web | title=Slam-dunking bunny makes it into record book | website=Sky News | date=September 7, 2017 | url=http://news.sky.com/video/slam-dunking-bunny-makes-it-into-record-book-11024075 | accessdate=September 10, 2017}} * {{cite web | title=Bini the slam-dunking bunny is better than you at basketball | website=Independent IE | date=September 7, 2017 | url=http://www.independent.ie/world-news/and-finally/bini-the-slamdunking-bunny-is-better-than-you-at-basketball-36109714.html | accessdate=September 10, 2017}} * {{cite web | title=The 2018 Guinness Book of World Records, in pictures | website=The Telegraph | date=September 7, 2017 | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/09/07/2018-guinness-book-world-records-pictures/bini-bunny-has-record-slam-dunks-rabbit | accessdate=September 10, 2017}}

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Total fertility rate}} {{Blacklisted-links|1= *http://www.econlib.org/library/Malthus/malPlong.html *:''Triggered by \beconlib\.org\b on the local blacklist'' *https://web.archive.org/web/20130828222107/http://www.econlib.org/library/Malthus/malPlong.html *:''Triggered by \beconlib\.org\b on the local blacklist''|bot=Cyberbot II|invisible=false}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} [[File:Countries by Birth Rate in 2017.svg|thumb|450px|Countries by crude birth rate (CBR) in 2017.]] The '''birth rate''' (technically, births/population rate) is the total number of live births per 1,000 in a population in a year or period.{{cite web|url=http://www.indexmundi.com/world/birth_rate.html |title=World Birth rate – Demographics |publisher=Indexmundi.com |accessdate=17 October 2011}} The rate of births in a population is calculated in several ways: live births from a universal registration system for births, deaths, and marriages; population counts from a [[census]], and estimation through specialized [[Demographics|demographic]] techniques. The birth rate (along with [[mortality rate|mortality]] and [[human migration|migration]] rate) are used to calculate [[population growth]]. The ''crude birth rate'' is the number of live births per year per 1,000 mid-year population.{{cite web|url=http://econ.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/DATASTATISTICS/0,,contentMDK:20451597~pagePK:64133150~piPK:64133175~theSitePK:239419,00.html|title=Data - Population and Demographic Indicators|website=econ.worldbank.org|access-date=2017-02-26}}See "[[Fertility rates]]"; Economic Geography Glossary at University of Washington Another term used interchangeably with ''birth rate'' is ''natality''.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/birthrate |title=birthrate – definition of birthrate by the Free Online Dictionary, Thesaurus and Encyclopedia |publisher=Thefreedictionary.com |accessdate=17 October 2011}} When the [[crude death rate]] is subtracted from the crude birth rate, the result is the [[rate of natural increase]] (RNI).{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.DYN.CBRT.IN |title=Birth rate, crude (per 1,000 people) | Data | Table |publisher=Data.worldbank.org |accessdate=17 October 2011}} This is equal to the rate of population change (excluding migration). The total (crude) birth rate (which includes all births)—typically indicated as births per 1,000 population—is distinguished from an age-specific rate (the number of births per 1,000 persons in an age group).{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/birth-rate |title=birthrate: Definition from |publisher=Answers.com |accessdate=17 October 2011}} The first known use of the term "birth rate" in English occurred in 1859.{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/birthrate |title=Birthrate – Definition and More from the Free Merriam-Webster Dictionary |publisher=Merriam-webster.com |accessdate=17 October 2011}}
{| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin: 0.5em 0 0.5em 1em; text-align:left" |+ World historical and projected crude birth rates (1950–2050)
UN, normal variant, 2009 rev.{{cite web|url=http://data.un.org/Data.aspx?q=world+population&d=PopDiv&f=variableID%3A53%3BcrID%3A900 |title=UNdata: Crude birth rate (per 1,000 population) |publisher=United Nations |date=25 August 2011 |accessdate=17 October 2011}} |- !Years!!CBR!!Years!!CBR |- |1950–1955||align=center|37.2||2000–2005||align=center|21.2 |- ||1955–1960||align=center|35.3||2005–2010||align=center|20.3 |- ||1960–1965||align=center|34.9||2010–2015||align=center|19.4 |- ||1965–1970||align=center|33.4||2015–2020||align=center|18.2 |- ||1970–1975||align=center|30.8||2020–2025||align=center|16.9 |- ||1975–1980||align=center|28.4||2025–2030||align=center|15.8 |- ||1980–1985||align=center|27.9||2030–2035||align=center|15.0 |- ||1985–1990||align=center|27.3||2035–2040||align=center|14.5 |- ||1990–1995||align=center|24.7||2040–2045||align=center|14.0 |- ||1995–2000||align=center|22.5||2045–2050||align=center|13.4 |}
The average global birth rate is 18.5 births per 1,000 total population in 2016.{{ cite web | date=2016 | url = https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/xx.html |title=CIA World Factbook. (Search for 'People and Society')}} The death rate is 7.8 per 1,000 per year. The RNI is thus 1.06 percent. In 2012 the average global birth rate was 19.611 according to the World Bank{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.DYN.CBRT.IN?end=2014&start=1976 |title=Birth rate, crude (per 1,000 people) | Data |website=Data.worldbank.org |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}} and 19.15 births per 1,000 total population according to the CIA,{{cite web|title=FIELD LISTING :: BIRTH RATE |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2054.html |work=Central Intelligence Agency - The World Factbook |publisher=Central Intelligence Agency |accessdate=4 June 2012 |author=Staff |year=2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211213638/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2054.html |archivedate=11 December 2007 |df=dmy }} compared to 20.09 per 1,000 total population in 2007.{{cite web|title=FIELD LISTING - BIRTH RATE |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2054.html |work=Central Intelligence Agency - The World Factbook |publisher=Central Intelligence Agency |accessdate=1 November 2012 |author=Staff |year=Dec 6, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211213638/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2054.html |archivedate=11 December 2007 }} The 2016 average of 18.6 births per 1,000 total population is estimated to be about 4.3 births/second or about 256 births/minute for the world. == Political issues == [[File:Familiy Planning Ethiopia (bad effects).jpg|thumbnail|Placard showing negative effects of lack of family planning and having too many [[child]]ren and [[infant]]s ([[Ethiopia]])]] The birth rate is an issue of concern and policy for national governments. Some (including those of [[Italy]] and [[Malaysia]]) seek to increase the birth rate with financial incentives or provision of support services to new mothers. Conversely, other countries have policies to reduce the birth rate (for example, China's [[one-child policy]] which was in effect from 1978 to 2015). Policies to increase the crude birth rate are known as pro-natalist policies, and policies to reduce the crude birth rate are known as anti-natalist policies. Measures such as improved information on [[birth control]] and its availability have achieved similar results in countries such as [[Family planning in Iran|Iran]]. There has also been discussion on whether bringing women into the forefront of development initiatives will lead to a decline in birth rates. In some countries, government policies have focused on reducing birth rates by improving women's rights, sexual and [[reproductive health]]. Typically, high birth rates are associated with health problems, low [[life expectancy]], low living standards, low [[social status]] for women and low educational levels. [[Demographic transition]] theory postulates that as a country undergoes [[economic development]] and social change its population growth declines, with birth rates serving as an indicator. At the 1974 [[World Population Conference]] in [[Bucharest]], [[Romania]], [[Women's rights#Modern movements|women's issues]] gained considerable attention. Family programs were discussed, and 137 countries drafted a World Population Plan of Action. As part of the discussion, many countries accepted modern [[birth control]] methods such as the [[birth control pill]] and the [[condom]] while opposing [[abortion]]. Population and the need to incorporate women into the discourse were discussed; it was agreed that improvements in women's status and initiatives in defense of reproductive health and freedom, the environment, and sustainable socioeconomic development were needed. Birth rates ranging from 10–20 births per 1,000 are considered low, while rates from 40–50 births per 1,000 are considered high.{{cite web|url=http://www.childtrends.org/?indicators=fertility-and-birth-rates|title=Fertility and Birth Rates|date=2015-03-24|website=Child Trends|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-17}} There are problems associated with both extremes. High birth rates may stress government welfare and family programs. Additional problems faced by a country with a high birth rate include educating a growing number of children, creating jobs for these children when they enter the workforce, and dealing with the environmental impact of a large population. Low birth rates may stress the government to provide adequate senior welfare systems and stress families who must support the elders themselves. There will be fewer children (and a working-age population) to support an aging population. == Coercive population control == In the 20th century, several authoritarian governments have sought either to increase or to decrease the birth rates, often through forceful intervention. One of the most notorious [[natalist]] policies is that which occurred in [[communist Romania]] in the period of 1967-1990 during communist leader [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]], who adopted a very aggressive natalist policy which included outlawing abortion and contraception, routine pregnancy tests for women, [[Tax on childlessness|taxes on childlessness]], and legal discrimination against childless people. This period has later been depicted in movies and documentaries (such as ''[[4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days]]'', ''[[Children of the Decree]]''). These policies temporarily increased birth rates for a few years, but this was followed by a later decline due to an increased use of [[illegal abortion]].{{cite web|url=http://humupd.oxfordjournals.org/content/16/6/590 |title=Europe the continent with the lowest fertility | Human Reproduction Update | Oxford Academic |website=Humupd.oxfordjournals.org |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}}{{cite web|author1=Mihai Horga1 |author2=Caitlin Gerdts |author3=Malcolm Potts |url=http://jfprhc.bmj.com/content/39/1/2.full |title=The remarkable story of Romanian women's struggle to manage their fertility | Journal of Family Planning and Reproductive Healthcare |website=Jfprhc.bmj.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}} Ceaușescu's policy resulted in over 9,000 women who died due to illegal abortions,Kligman, Gail. "Political Demography: The Banning of Abortion in Ceausescu's Romania". In Ginsburg, Faye D.; Rapp, Rayna, eds. ''Conceiving the New World Order: The Global Politics of Reproduction.'' Berkeley, CA: University of California Press, 1995 :234-255. Unique Identifier : AIDSLINE KIE/49442. large numbers of children put into [[Romanian orphanages]] by parents who couldn't cope with raising them, [[street children]] in the 1990s (when many orphanages were closed and the children ended on the streets), and [[overcrowding]] in homes and schools. The irony of [[Nicolae Ceaușescu|Ceaușescu's]] aggressive natalist policy was a generation that may not have been born would eventually lead the [[Romanian Revolution]] which would overthrow and have him [[Trial of Nicolae and Elena Ceaușescu#Execution|executed]].{{Cite book|title=Freakonomics|last=Levitt & Dubner|first=Steven & Stephen|publisher=Penguin Group|year=2005|isbn=9780141019017|location=80 Strand, London WC2R ORL England|page=107|quote=}} In stark opposition with Ceaușescu's natalist policy was China's [[one child policy]], in effect from 1978 to 2015, which included abuses such as [[forced abortion]]s.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-18435126 |title=China forced abortion photo sparks outrage - BBC News |website=Bbc.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}} This policy has also been deemed responsible for the common practice of [[sex selective abortion]] which led to an imbalanced [[sex ratio]] in the country. Given strict family-size limitations and a preference for sons, girls have become unwanted in China because they are considered as depriving the parents of the possibility of having a son. With the progress of prenatal sex-determination technologies and induced abortion, the one-child policy gradually turned into a one-son policy.{{cite journal|last=Bulte, E., Heerink, N., & Zhang, X.|title=China’s one-child policy and ‘the mystery of missing women’: ethnic minorities and male-biased sex ratios.|journal=Oxford Bulletin of Economics and Statistics|year=2011|volume=73|issue=1|pages=0305–9049|doi=10.1111/j.1468-0084.2010.00601.x}} In many countries, the steady decline in birth rates over the past decades can be greatly attributed to the significant gains in women's freedoms, such as tackling the phenomenon of [[forced marriage]] and [[child marriage]], education for women and increased socioeconomic opportunities. Women of all economic, social, religious and educational persuasions are choosing to have fewer children as they are gaining more control over their own [[reproductive rights]]. Apart from more children living into their adult years, women are often more ambitious to take up work, education and living their own lives rather than just a life of reproduction.{{Cite book|title=People Quake|last=Pearse|first=Fred|publisher=Eden Project Books|year=2010|isbn=9781905811342|location=61-63 Uxbridge Road, London W5 5SA|pages=P131|quote=}} Birth rates in third world countries have fallen due to the introduction of [[family planning]] clinics. In Bangladesh, one of the poorest countries in the world, women are on average having two children less often than they did before 1999, according to Australian demographer Jack Caldwell. Bangladeshi women eagerly took up contraceptives, like condoms and the pill, on offer from a foreign population agency in a study by the World Bank carried out in 1994. The study proved that family planning could be carried out and accepted practically anywhere. Caldwell also believes that agricultural improvements led to the need for less labour. Children not needed to plough the fields would be of surplus and require some education, so in turn, smaller families, and with smaller families, women are able to work and have greater ambitions.{{Cite book|title=People Quake|last=Pearse|first=Fred|publisher=Eden Project Books|year=2010|isbn=9781905811342|location=61-63 Uxbridge Road, London W5 5SA|pages=P133-136|quote=}} [[Myanmar]], a country which until 2011 was controlled by an austere military junta, intent on controlling every aspect of its population's lives. The military generals wanted the country's population doubled. In their view, The women's job was to produce babies to power the country's labour force, so family planning was vehemently opposed. The women of Burma opposed this policy, and Peter McDonald of the Australian National University argues that this gave rise to a [[black market]] trade in contraception, all smuggled from neighbouring Thailand.{{Cite book|title=People Quake|last=Pearse|first=Fred|publisher=Eden Project Books|year=2010|isbn=9781905811342|location=61-63 Uxbridge Road, London W5 5SA|pages=P136|quote=}} In 1990, five years after the war ended, Iran saw the fastest recorded drop in fertility in world history. Revolution gave way to consumerism and westernization. With TVs and cars came condoms and the pill. A generation of women expected to produce soldiers in the fight against Iraq was met by the next generation of women who had a choice to enjoy some new found luxuries. In the years during the Iran/Iraq war, the women of Iran averaged about 8 children each, a ratio the hard line Islamic President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad wanted to revive. As of 2010, the birth rate of Iran is 1.7 babies per woman. Some may say this is a triumph of western values, which give women more freedoms, over an Islamic ruled state.{{Cite book|title=People Quake|last=Pearse|first=Fred|publisher=Eden Project Books|year=2010|isbn=9781905811342|location=61-63 Uxbridge Road, London W5 5SA|pages=P137-139|quote=}} Islamic clerics are having less influence over women in other Muslim countries also. In the past 30 years Turkey`s fertility rate of children per woman has dropped from 4.07 to 2.08. Tunisia has dropped from 4.82 to 2.14 and Morocco from 5.4 to 2.52 children per woman.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldometers.info/world-population/australia-population/|title=worldmeters|last=Staff|first=|date=22 October 2016|website=www.worldmeters.info|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-22}} Latin America, of predominately Catholic faith, has seen the same trends in falling fertility rates. Brazilian women are having half the children they were 25 years ago with a rate of 2.2 children per woman. The Vatican is having less influence over women in other hard-line Catholic countries also. Mexico, El Salvador, Ecuador, Nicaragua, Colombia, Venezuela and Peru have all seen significant drops in fertility in the same period, all going from over six to less than three children per woman. Forty percent of married Brazilian women are choosing to get sterilised after having children, but this may be a compromise as it is only one confession of sin to the church. Some may say this is a triumph of Western values, which give women more freedoms, over a Catholic state.{{Cite book|title=People Quake|last=Pearse|first=Fred|publisher=Eden Project Books|year=2010|isbn=9781905811342|location=61-62 Uxbridge Road, London W5 5SA|pages=P140|quote=}} == {{anchor|Birth rate in different countries}}National birth rates == According to the CIA's ''[[The World Factbook]]'',{{when|date=June 2018}} the country with the highest birth rate is Niger (at 51.26 births per 1,000 people). The country with the lowest birth rate is Monaco, at 6.72 births per thousand.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} Compared with the 1950s (when the birth rate was 36 per thousand), as of 2011, the world birth rate has declined by 16 per thousand.{{cite web |url=http://www.uneca.org/eca_programmes/food_security_and_sustainability/programme_overview/population/fertility/crude_world.htm |title=Crude Birth Rates – The World and its Major Regions, 1950–2050 |publisher=uneca.org |accessdate=17 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816073652/http://www.uneca.org/eca_programmes/food_security_and_sustainability/programme_overview/population/fertility/crude_world.htm |archivedate=16 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }} As of 2017, Niger has the highest birth rate in the world with 49.443 per thousand people.{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.DYN.CBRT.IN?end=2014&locations=NE&start=1976 |title=Birth rate, crude (per 1,000 people) | Data |website=Data.worldbank.org |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}} Japan has one of the lowest birth rates in the world with 8 per thousand people.{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.DYN.CBRT.IN?end=2014&locations=JP&start=1976 |title=Birth rate, crude (per 1,000 people) | Data |website=Data.worldbank.org |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}} While in Japan there are 126 million people{{cite web|url=http://populationpyramid.net/japan/2016/ |title=Population Pyramid of Japan in 2016 |website=Populationpyramid.net |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}} and in Niger 21 million,{{cite web|url=http://populationpyramid.net/niger/2016/ |title=Population Pyramid of Niger in 2016 |website=Populationpyramid.net |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}} both countries had around 1 million babies born in 2016. ===Sub-Saharan Africa=== The region of [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] has the highest birth rate in the world. As of 2016, [[Niger]], [[Mali]], [[Uganda]], [[Zambia]], and [[Burundi]] have the highest birth rates in the world.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2054rank.html |title=The World Factbook — Central Intelligence Agency |website=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}} This is part of the [[Income and fertility|fertility-income paradox]], as these countries are very poor, and it may seem counter-intuitive for families there to have so many children. The inverse relationship between income and fertility has been termed a ''demographic-economic "[[paradox]]"'' by the notion that greater means would enable the production of more offspring as suggested by the influential [[Thomas Malthus]].{{citation|url=http://www.econlib.org/library/Malthus/malPlong.html|title=An Essay on the Principle of Population|first=Thomas Robert|last=Malthus|year=1826|publisher=London: John Murray|edition=6|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130828222107/http://www.econlib.org/library/Malthus/malPlong.html|archivedate=28 August 2013}} ===Afghanistan=== [[Afghanistan]] has the 11th highest birth rate in the world, and also the highest birth rate of any non-African country (as of 2016). The rapid population growth of Afghanistan is considered a problem by preventing population stabilization, and affecting maternal and infant health.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurasianet.org/node/64019 |title=Afghanistan: Population Boom Threatens Stabilization Chances |website=EurasiaNet.org |date=2011-08-09 |accessdate=2017-03-11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/news/2008/07/14/high-birth-rate-killing-mothers-infants-unfpa-expert |title=IRIN | High birth rate killing mothers, infants - UNFPA expert |website=Irinnews.org |date=2008-07-14 |accessdate=2017-03-11}} Reasons for large families include tradition, religion, the low status of women and the cultural desire to have several sons.{{cite web|url=https://womennewsnetwork.net/2012/05/29/afghanistan-large-families/ |title=AFGHANISTAN: Large families encouraged by culture as well as religion | Women News Network / WNN Global |website=Womennewsnetwork.net |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}} === Australia === Historically, [[Australia]] has had a relatively low fertility rate, reaching a high of 3.14 births per woman in 1960.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldometers.info/world-population/australia-population/|title=Australian Population|last=Staff|first=|date=2016-10-23|website=www.worldometers.info|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-23}} This was followed by a decline which continued until the mid-2000, when a one off cash incentive was introduced to reverse the decline. In 2004, the then [[Howard government]] introduced a non-means tested 'Maternity Payment' to parents of every newborn as a substitute to maternity leave. The payment known as the 'Baby Bonus' was A$3000 per child. This rose to A$5000 which was paid in 13 instalments.{{cite web|url=http://mccrindle.com.au/the-mccrindle-blog/the-baby-bonus-generation|title=The Baby Bonus Generation|last=Staff|first=|date=2013-05-15|website=www.mccrindle.com.au|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-23}} At a time when Australia's unemployment was at a 28-year low of 5.2%, the then Treasurer [[Peter Costello]] stated there was opportunity to go lower. With a good economic outlook for Australia, Costello held the view that now was a good time to expand the population, with his famous quote that every family should have three children "one for mum, one for dad and one for the country".{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2004/s1261874.htm|title=ABC TV Transcript|last=Costello|first=Peter|date=2004-12-09|website=www.abc.net.au|publisher=Australian Broadcast Commission|access-date=2016-10-23}} Australia's fertility rate reached a peak of 1.95 children per woman in 2010, a 30-year high, although still [[Sub-replacement fertility|below replacement rate]]. Phil Ruthven of the business information firm IBISWorld believes the spike in fertility was more about timing and less about monetary incentives. Generation X was now aged 25 to 45 years old. With numerous women putting pregnancies off for a few years for the sake of a career, many felt the years closing in and their biological clocks ticking.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2007/s1963979.htm|title=ABC Radio Transcript|last=Ruthven|first=Phil|date=2007-06-27|website=www.abc.net.au|publisher=Australian Broadcast Commission|access-date=2016-10-23}} On 1 March 2014, the baby bonus was replaced with Family Tax Benefit A. By then the baby bonus had left its legacy on Australia.{{cite web|url=http://mccrindle.com.au/the-mccrindle-blog/the-baby-bonus-generation|title=The McCrindle Blog|last=Staff|first=|date=2013-05-15|website=www.mccrindle.com.au|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-23}} In 2016, Australia's fertility rate has only decreased slightly to 1.91 children per woman. '''Canada''' {{cns|date=November 2018|text=Canada's birthrate is 1.60 births per woman as of 2015, more closely resembling a European country than Australia or the USA.}} === France === [[France]] has been successful in increasing fertility rates from the low levels seen in the late 1980s, after a continuous fall in the birth rate.{{Cite journal|last=이(Yi)|first=문숙(Moun Souk)|date=Winter 2016|title=프랑스의 저출산 문제 해소 요인 (Resolved Factors to Low Fertility in France)|url=|journal=한국콘텐츠학회논문지(Journal of the Korea contents association)|volume=16 |issue=1|pages=558|via=}} In 1994, the total fertility rate was as low as 1.66, but perhaps due to the active family policy of the government in the mid 1990s, it has increased, and maintained an average of 2.0 average from 2008 until 2015. France has embarked on a strong incentive policy based on two key measures to restore the birth rate: family benefits (''les allocations familiales'') and a family-coefficient of income tax (''le quotient familial'').{{Cite journal|last=이(Yi)|first=문숙(Moun Souk)|date=Winter 2016|title=프랑스의 저출산 문제 해소 요인 (Resolved Factors to Low Fertility in France)|url=|journal=한국콘텐츠학회논문지(Journal of the Korea contents association)|volume=16 |issue=1|pages=561|via=}} Since the end of World War II, early family policy in France has been based on a family tradition that requires children to support multi-child family, so that a third child enables a multi-child family to benefit from family allowances and income tax exemptions. This is intended to allow families with three children to enjoy the same living standards as households without children. In particular, the French income taxation system is structured so that families with children receive tax breaks greater than single adults without children.{{Cite journal|last=이(Yi)|first=문숙(Moun Souk)|date=Winter 2016|title=프랑스의 저출산 문제 해소 요인 (Resolved Factors to Low Fertility in France)|url=|journal=한국콘텐츠학회논문지(Journal of the Korea contents association)|volume=16 |issue=1|pages=562|via=}} This income tax imposition system is known as the family coefficient of income tax. A characteristic of the family factor is that households with a large number of children, even if they are at the same standard of living, can receive more tax exemption benefits. Since the 1970s, the focus has been on supporting families who are vulnerable such as single parent families and the children of a poor family in order to ensure equality of opportunity.{{Cite journal|last=이(Yi)|first=문숙(Moun Souk)|date=Winter 2016|title=프랑스의 저출산 문제 해소 요인 (Resolved Factors to Low Fertility in France)|url=|journal=한국콘텐츠학회논문지(Journal of the Korea contents association)|volume=16 |issue=1|pages=563|via=}} In addition, as many women began to participate in the labor market, the government introduced policies of financial support for childcare leave as well as childcare facilities. In 1994, the government expanded the parent education allowance (''l'allocation parentale d'éducation'') for women with two children to ensure freedom of choice and reduce formal unemployment in order to promote family well-being and women's labor participation. There are also: * an infant child care allowance, family allowance and family allowance for multichild family, and a multi-element family pension scheme.{{Cite journal|last=이(Yi)|first=문숙(Moun Souk)|date=Winter 2016|title=프랑스의 저출산 문제 해소 요인 (Resolved Factors to Low Fertility in France)|url=|journal=한국콘텐츠학회논문지(Journal of the Korea contents association)|volume=16 |issue=1|pages=564|via=}} *a medical insurance system that covers all medical expenses, hospitalization costs, and medical expenses incurred after six months of pregnancy as 100% of the national health insurance in the national social security system, and the statutory leave system during pregnancy. ===Germany=== The birth rate in [[Germany]] is only 8.3 per thousand—so low that the UK and France (which have smaller populations) had more births in the past year.{{cite news| url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/health/2011/0809/1224302081071.html | work=The Irish Times | title=Germany faces up to its kinder surprise | date=9 August 2011}} ===Ireland=== In Europe as of July 2011, Ireland's birth rate was 16.5 per 1000 (3.5 percent higher than the next-ranked country, the UK).{{cite web|author=Susan Daly |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/ireland-has-one-of-highest-birth-and-lowest-death-rates-in-eu-189080-Jul2011/ |title=Ireland has one of highest birth and lowest death rates in EU · TheJournal |publisher=Thejournal.ie |accessdate=17 October 2011}} ===Japan=== [[File:Japan Population by Age 1920-2010 with Projection to 2060.png|thumb|upright=0.9|Historic population of [[Japan]] (1920-2010) with projected population (2011-2060).]] As of 2016, [[Japan]] has the third lowest crude birth rate (i.e. not allowing for the population's age distribution) in the world, with only [[Saint Pierre and Miquelon]] and [[Monaco]] having lower crude birth rates. Japan has an unbalanced population with many elderly but few young people, and the this is projected to be more extreme in the future, unless there are major changes. An increasing number of Japanese people are staying unmarried: between 1980 and 2010, the percentage of the population who had never married increased from 22% to almost 30%, even as the population continued to age, and by 2035 one in four people will not marry during their childbearing years.{{cite news|last1=Yoshida|first1=Reiji|title=Japan’s population dilemma, in a single-occupancy nutshell|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/12/31/national/social-issues/japans-population-dilemma-single-occupancy-nutshell/|accessdate=14 January 2016|work=The Japan Times|date=31 December 2015}} The Japanese sociologist [[Masahiro Yamada]] coined the term "[[parasite single]]s" for unmarried adults in their late 20s and 30s who continue to live with their parents.{{cite web|last=Wiseman |first=Paul |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/world/2004-06-02-japan-women-usat_x.htm |title=USATODAY.com - No sex please we're Japanese |website=Usatoday30.usatoday.com |date=2004-06-02 |accessdate=2017-03-11}} ===Taiwan=== In August 2011 Taiwan's government announced that its birth rate declined in the previous year, despite the fact that the government implemented approaches to encourage fertility.{{cite news|last=Sui |first=Cindy |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-14525525 |title=BBC News – Taiwanese birth rate plummets despite measures |publisher=BBC |date=15 August 2011 |accessdate=17 October 2011}} ===United Kingdom=== In July 2011, the UK's [[Office for National Statistics]] (ONS) announced a 2.4 percent increase in live births in the UK in 2010.{{cite news|author=Press Association |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2011/jul/13/more-midwives-birth-rate-40-year-high |title=Call for more midwives as birth rate reaches 40-year high | Society | guardian.co.uk |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=17 October 2011 |date=13 July 2011}} This is the highest birth rate in the UK in 40 years. However, the UK record year for births and birth rate remains 1920 (when the ONS reported over 957,000 births to a population of "around 40 million").{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-16853368|title=Go Figure: When was the real baby boom?|publisher=BBC news magazine|author=Michael Blastland|date=2 February 2012|accessdate=5 April 2012}} ===United States=== According to U.S. federal-government data released in March 2011, births fell four percent from 2007 to 2009 (the largest drop in the U.S. for any two-year period since the 1970s).{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/mar/31/news/la-heb-us-birth-rate-falls-20110331 |title=Us Birth Rate | U.S. birth rate: Drop in birth rate is the biggest in 30 years – Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=31 March 2011 |accessdate=17 October 2011 |first=Shari |last=Roan}} Births have declined for three consecutive years, and are now seven percent below the 2007 peak.{{cite web|author=Bill McBride |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/americas-birth-rate-declined-for-the-third-year-running-2011-8#ixzz1V1D2X8rk |title=America's Birth Rate Declined For The Third Year Running |publisher=Businessinsider.com |date=12 August 2011 |accessdate=17 October 2011}} This drop has continued through 2010, according to data released by the U.S. National Center for Health Statistics in June 2011.{{cite web|author=Bill McBride |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/americas-birth-rate-declined-for-the-third-year-running-2011-8 |title=America's Birth Rate Declined For The Third Year Running |publisher=Businessinsider.com |date=12 August 2011 |accessdate=17 October 2011}} Experts have suggested that this decline is a reflection of unfavorable economic conditions.{{cite news|url=http://yourlife.usatoday.com/parenting-family/story/2011/08/CDC-Childbearing-today-much-like-Depression-era/49928146/1?csp=34news |title=Economic turmoil taking its toll on childbearing |work=USA Today |date=11 August 2011 |accessdate=17 October 2011}} The connection between birth rate and economic conditions stems from the fact that US birth rates have fallen to levels comparable to those during the [[Great Depression in the United States|Great Depression]] during the 1930s.{{cite web |url=http://www.wzzm13.com/news/article/175311/14/Lower-birth-rate-blamed-on-the-economy |title=Lower birth rate blamed on the economy |publisher=wzzm13.com |date=12 August 2011 |accessdate=17 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130209221819/http://www.wzzm13.com/news/article/175311/14/Lower-birth-rate-blamed-on-the-economy |archivedate=9 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }} A state-level look at fertility, based on a report published by the Pew Research Center in October 2011, points out the strong correlation between lower birth rates and economic distress. In 2008, North Dakota had the nation's lowest unemployment rate (3.1 percent) and was the only state to show an increase (0.7 percent) in its birth rate. All other states either remained the same or declined. The research center's study also found evidence of a correlation between economic difficulties and fertility decline by race and ethnicity. Hispanics (particularly affected by the recession) have experienced the largest fertility decline, particularly compared to Caucasians (who have less economic hardship and a smaller decline in fertility). In 2008–2009 the birth rate declined 5.9 percent for Hispanic women, 2.4 percent for African American women and 1.6 percent for white women. The relatively large birth rate declines among Hispanics mirror their relatively large economic declines, in terms of jobs and wealth. According to the statistics using the data from National Centre for Health Statistics and U.S. Census Bureau, from 2007 to 2008, the employment rate among Hispanics declined by 1.6 percentage points, compared with declines of 0.7 points for whites. The unemployment rate shows a similar pattern—unemployment among Hispanics increased 2.0 percentage points from 2007 to 2008, while for whites the increase was 0.9 percentage points. A recent report from the Pew Hispanic Center revealed that Hispanics have also been the biggest losers in terms of wealth since the beginning of the recession, with Hispanic households losing 66% of their median wealth from 2005 to 2009. In comparison, black households lost 53% of their median wealth and white households lost only 16%. In facts, Hispanics, who have been hit the hardest in terms of employment and wealth, have also experienced the largest fertility declines since the onset of the recession because the birth rate declines of Hispanic women is the highest while comparing to the White women. Since, the unemployment rate has been increasing, the birth rate decline has been decreasing.{{cite web|last1=Livingston|first1=Gretchen|title=In a Down Economy, Fewer Births|url=http://www.pewsocialtrends.org/2011/10/12/in-a-down-economy-fewer-births/|website=Pew Research Center|accessdate=29 March 2017}} Other factors (such as women's labor-force participation, contraceptive technology and public policy) make it difficult to determine how much economic change affect fertility. Research suggests that much of the fertility decline during an economic downturn is a postponement of childbearing, not a decision to have fewer (or no) children; people plan to "catch up" to their plans of bearing children when economic conditions improve. Younger women are more likely than older women to postpone pregnancy due to economic factors, since they have more years of fertility remaining.{{cite web|url=http://www.pewsocialtrends.org/2011/10/12/in-a-down-economy-fewer-births/?src=prc-headline |title=In a Down Economy, Fewer Births | Pew Research Center |website=Pewsocialtrends.org |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}} In July 2011, the [[U.S. National Institutes of Health]] announced that the adolescent birth rate continues to decline.{{cite web|url=http://www.nih.gov/news/health/jul2011/nichd-07.htm |title=Federal report shows drop in adolescent birth rate, July 7, 2011 News Release – National Institutes of Health (NIH) |publisher=Nih.gov |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate=17 October 2011}} In 2013, teenage birth rates in the U.S. were at the lowest level in U.S. history.{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/teenpregnancy/about/index.htm |title=About Teen Pregnancy |publisher=Cdc.gov |accessdate=12 May 2015}} Teen birth rates in the U.S. have decreased from 1991 through 2012 (except for an increase from 2005–2007). The other aberration from this otherwise-steady decline in teen birth rates is the six percent decrease in birth rates for 15- to 19-year-olds between 2008 and 2009. Despite the decrease, U.S. teen birth rates remain higher than those in other developed nations. Racial differences affect teen birth and pregnancy rates: American Indian/Alaska Native, Hispanic, and non-Hispanic black teen pregnancy rates are more than double the non-Hispanic white teenage birth rate.{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/features/dsTeenPregnancy/#source |title=CDC Data & Statistics | Feature: Teen Birth Rates Declined Again in 2009 |publisher=Cdc.gov |date=1 July 2011 |accessdate=17 October 2011}} States strict in enforcing child support have up to 20 percent fewer unmarried births than states that are lax about getting unmarried dads to pay, the researchers found. Moreover, according to the results, if all 50 states in the United States had done at least as well in their enforcement efforts as the state ranked fifth from the top, that would have led to a 20 percent reduction in out-of-wedlock births.{{cite web|url=http://uwnews.org/article.asp?articleid=10608 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070505175913/http://uwnews.org/article.asp?articleid=10608 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-05-05 |title=uwnews.org | Tough child support laws may deter single men from becoming fathers, study finds | University of Washington News and Information |date= |accessdate=2017-03-11}} The United States population growth is at an historical low level as the United States current birth rates are the lowest ever recorded.{{cite web|title=Baby bust: U.S. births at record low|url=http://money.cnn.com/2013/09/06/news/economy/birth-rate-low/|publisher=CNN|date=September 6, 2014}} The low birth rates in the contemporary United States can possibly be ascribed to the recession, which led women to postpone having children and fewer immigrants coming to the US. The current US birth rates are not high enough to maintain the size of the U.S. population, according to [[The Economist]].{{cite web|title= Population gains at near-historic lows|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/district-population-booms-in-2013/2013/12/30/1ac8515e-7162-11e3-9389-09ef9944065e_story.html?hpid=z4|publisher=The Washington Post|date=April 19, 2014}}{{cite web|title=U.S. Birth Rate Not High Enough To Keep Population Stable|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/15/us-birth-rate_n_1779960.html|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=April 19, 2014}} ==Factors affecting birth rate== {{Main|Fertility factor (demography)}} [[File:2018 UN Human Development Report.svg|thumb|[[Human Development Index]] map. Darker is higher. Countries with a higher HDI usually have a lower birth rate, known as the [[Income and fertility|fertility-income paradox]].]] There are many factors that interact in complex ways, influencing the births rate of a population. [[Developed countries]] have a lower birth rate than [[underdeveloped countries]] (see [[Income and fertility]]). A parent's number of children strongly correlates with the number of children that each person in the next generation will eventually have.{{cite journal|last1=Murphy|first1=Michael|title=Cross-National Patterns of Intergenerational Continuities in Childbearing in Developed Countries|journal=Biodemography and Social Biology|volume=59|issue=2|year=2013|pages=101–126|issn=1948-5565|doi=10.1080/19485565.2013.833779}} Factors generally associated with increased fertility include [[religiosity]],{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1353/sof.0.0000| title = Religiosity and Fertility in the United States: The Role of Fertility Intentions| journal = Social Forces| volume = 86| issue = 3| page = 1163| year = 2008| last1 = Hayford | first1 = S. R.| last2 = Morgan | first2 = S. P.| pmc = 2723861}} intention to have children,{{cite web|url=http://www.ssb.no/en/forskning/discussion-papers/_attachment/182990?_ts=146a3818d38|author1=Lars Dommermuth |author2=Jane Klobas |author3=Trude Lappegård |title=Differences in childbearing by time frame of fertility intention. A study using survey and register data from Norway|year=2014}} Part of the research project Family Dynamics, Fertility Choices and Family Policy (FAMDYN) and maternal support.{{cite journal|last1=Schaffnit|first1=S. B.|last2=Sear|first2=R.|title=Wealth modifies relationships between kin and women's fertility in high-income countries|journal=Behavioral Ecology|volume=25|issue=4|year=2014|pages=834–842|issn=1045-2249|doi=10.1093/beheco/aru059}} Factors generally associated with decreased fertility include [[Income and fertility|wealth]], education,{{cite journal|title=Regression Analysis of Collinear Data using r-k Class Estimator: Socio-Economic and Demographic Factors Affecting the Total Fertility Rate (TFR) in India.|journal=Journal of Data Science|year=2013|volume=11|last1=Rai|first1=Piyush Kant|last2=Pareek|first2=Sarla|last3=Joshi|first3=Hemlata|url=http://www.jds-online.com/file_download/394/JDS-1130.pdf}} [[female labor participation]],{{cite journal |first=David |last=Bloom |first2=David |last2=Canning |first3=Günther |last3=Fink |first4=Jocelyn |last4=Finlay |year=2009 |title=Fertility, female labor force participation, and the demographic dividend |journal=[[Journal of Economic Growth]] |volume=14 |issue=2 |pages=79–101 |doi=10.1007/s10887-009-9039-9 }} [[urban area|urban]] residence,{{citation|url=http://ir.nul.nagoya-u.ac.jp/jspui/bitstream/2237/8650/1/ysatoJUE.pdf|title=Economic geography, fertility and migration|first=Yasuhiro|last=Sato|journal=Journal of Urban Economics|date=30 July 2006|accessdate=31 March 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160206181059/http://ir.nul.nagoya-u.ac.jp/jspui/bitstream/2237/8650/1/ysatoJUE.pdf|archive-date=6 February 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} [[intelligence and fertility|intelligence]], [[age and female fertility|increased female age]] and (to a lesser degree) [[paternal age effect|increased male age]]. Many of these factors however are not universal, and differ by region and social class. For instance, at a global level, religion is correlated with increased fertility, but in the West less so: Scandinavian countries and France are among the least religious in the EU, but have the highest TFR, while the opposite is true about Portugal, Greece, Cyprus, Poland and Spain. (see [[Religion in the European Union]]).{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/tgm/table.do?tab=table&init=1&language=en&pcode=tsdde220&plugin=0 |title=Eurostat - Tables, Graphs and Maps Interface (TGM) table |website=Ec.europa.eu |date=2016-08-11 |accessdate=2017-03-11}} [[Reproductive health]] can also affect the birth rate, as untreated infections can lead to fertility problems, as can be seen in the "infertility belt" - a region that stretches across central Africa from the United Republic of Tanzania in the east to Gabon in the west, and which has a lower fertility than other African regions.{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/88/12/10-011210/en/|title=WHO - Mother or nothing: the agony of infertility|website=www.who.int}}{{cite journal| pmid=2900173 | volume=26 | title=Infertility in Central Africa: infection is the cause | year=1988 | journal=Int J Gynaecol Obstet | pages=423–8 | last1 = Collet | first1 = M | last2 = Reniers | first2 = J | last3 = Frost | first3 = E | last4 = Gass | first4 = R | last5 = Yvert | first5 = F | last6 = Leclerc | first6 = A | last7 = Roth-Meyer | first7 = C | last8 = Ivanoff | first8 = B | last9 = Meheus | first9 = A | doi=10.1016/0020-7292(88)90340-2}} Child custody laws, affecting fathers' parental rights over their children from birth until child custody ends at age 18, may have an effect on the birth rate. [[U.S. state]]s strict in enforcing [[child support]] have up to 20 percent fewer unmarried births than states that are lax about getting unmarried fathers to pay, the researchers found. Moreover, according to the results, if all 50 states in the United States had done at least as well in their enforcement efforts as the state ranked fifth from the top, that would have led to a 20 percent reduction in out-of-wedlock births. == See also == * [[Death rate]] * [[Human overpopulation]] * [[Human population control]] * [[Population aging]] * [[Population decline]] * [[Total fertility rate]] ;Case studies * [[Aging of Europe]] * [[Aging of Japan]] ;Lists * [[List of sovereign states and dependent territories by birth rate]] * [[List of sovereign states and dependent territories by fertility rate]] ;Organizations * [[Population Matters]] (formerly known as the Optimum Population Trust) ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091025061004/http://esa.un.org/unpp/index.asp?panel=7 United Nations World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision Population Database] * {{cite book |title= Longman Dictionary of Geography, Human and Physical |last= Audrey |first= Clark |year=1985 |publisher=Longman |location= New York }} * {{cite book |title= Companion Encyclopedia of Geography |last= Douglas |first= Ian |author2=Richard Huggett |year= 2007 |publisher=Routledge |location= New York}} * Norwood, Carolette. "Re-thinking the integration of women in population development initiatives" Development in Practice. 19.7(2009):906 – 911. * [http://www.indexmundi.com/world/birth_rate.html World Birth rate by IndexMundi] * http://www.childtrends.org/?indicators=fertility-and-birth-rates == External links == {{Commonscatinline|Birth and death rates}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071211213638/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2054.html CIA World Factbook Birth Rate List by Rank] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Birth Rate}} [[Category:Human overpopulation]] [[Category:Population ecology]] [[Category:Demographic economics]] [[Category:Fertility]] [[Category:Ageing]] [[Category:Temporal rates]]

{{italic title}} '''''Brulion''''' (meaning ''Rough Sketchbook'' in English) was a [[Polish language]] quarterly literary [[magazine]] published in Poland from 1986 to 1999.
==History and profile== ''Brulion'' was established by a group led by Robert Tekieli in [[Kraków]] in 1986.<ref name="Phillips2013">{{cite book|author=Ursula Phillips|title=Polish Literature in Transformation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fFNeAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA252|accessdate=10 November 2014|date=25 January 2013|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|isbn=978-3-643-90289-4|page=252}}</ref><ref name=mathe>{{cite book|author1=Matthias Schwartz|author2=Heike Winkel|title=Eastern European Youth Cultures in a Global Context|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rWT-CgAAQBAJ&pg=PA162|accessdate=24 April 2016|edition=mathe|date=30 November 2015|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-1-137-38513-0|page=162}}</ref> The magazine, published quarterly, ceased publication in 1999.<ref name=Phillips2013/>
Its [[editor in chief]] was also Robert Tekieli. Originally a quarterly of the alternative and semi-legal [[Polish culture]], it became known for respecting no taboos and producing scandals since its ninth issue, thus becoming the voice of the [[Resistance movement|underground]], [[anti-communism|anti-communist]] Poland. The generation of ''brulion'' writers was influenced mainly by [[List of poets from the United States|American poets]] like [[Frank O'Hara]] (that is why they're often called ''o´harists''), [[Allen Ginsberg]] or [[John Ashbery]], translated by Pietr Sommer. Another translator, Stanisław Barańczak, introduced to Poland the poetry of [[Philip Larkin]], [[W. H. Auden]], [[Robert Frost]] and others. ''Brulion'' published among others an almanac named ''Przyszli barbarzyńci'' (''Future barbarians''; the title comes from a poem by [[Konstantinos Kavafis|Cavafy]]). Therefore, the ''brulion'' generation is also known as ''barbarians''.<ref name="mathe"/>
==The best known ''brulion'' authors== * [[Marcin Baran]] * [[Miłosz Biedrzycki]] * [[Marzena Broda]] * [[Paweł Filas]] * [[Natasza Goerke]] * [[Manuela Gretkowska]] * [[Krzysztof Jaworski (poet)|Krzysztof Jaworski]] * [[Krzysztof Koehler]] * [[Cezary Michalski]] * [[Jacek Podsiadło]] * [[Marcin Sendecki]] * [[Mirosław Spychalski]] * [[Marcin Świetlicki]] * [[Olga Tokarczuk]] * [[Grzegorz Wróblewski]]
==References== {{Reflist}} *''Bílé propasti'' (''White Abysses''), Host, [[Brno]], 1997, p. 181-9.
[[Category:1986 establishments in Poland]] [[Category:1999 disestablishments in Poland]] [[Category:Defunct magazines of Poland]] [[Category:Defunct literary magazines of Europe]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1986]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1999]] [[Category:Media in Kraków]] [[Category:Polish literary magazines]] [[Category:Polish-language magazines]] [[Category:Quarterly magazines]]

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2018}} Located in [[Bern]], [[Switzerland]], the '''Camerata Bern''' was founded in 1963 as a flexible [[chamber orchestra]] without a [[conducting|conductor]]. The Camerata Bern performs early Baroque to contemporary classical music. The group tours extensively worldwide and is releasing CD recordings regularly.
The artistic director as of the season 2018–19 is [[Patricia Kopatchinskaja]] and the fifteen members are:
Violin * Hyunjong Kang * Claudia Ajmone-Marsan * Meesun Hong Coleman * Sibylla Leuenberger * Michael Bollin * Christina Merblum * Suyeon Kang * Sonja Starke
Viola * Anna Puig-Torné * Alejandro Mettler * Friedemann Jähnig
Cello * Thomas Kaufmann * Martin Merker
Double bass * Käthi Steuri
Harpsichord * Vital Julian Frey
==External links== *[http://www.cameratabern.ch/index.html Camerata Bern Official Website]

{{other uses|St. Nicholas' Cathedral (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox religious building | building_name = Cathedral of Our Lady Immaculate
{{lang|fr|Cathédrale de Notre-Dame-Immaculée}} | infobox_width = | image = Monaco BW 2011-06-07 16-07-20.jpg | image_size = | caption = Facade of the Monaco Cathedral | map_type = | map_size = | map_caption = | location = Monaco-Ville, Monaco | geo = {{coord|43.730214|7.422664|display=title,inline|format=dms|type:landmark_source:dewiki}} | latitude = | longitude = | religious_affiliation = [[Roman Catholic Church]] | rite = | region = | state = | province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Monaco|Archdiocese of Monaco]] | territory = | prefecture = | sector = | district = | cercle = | municipality = | consecration_year = 1911 | status = [[Cathedral]] | functional_status = Active | heritage_designation = | leadership = | website = | architecture = yes | architect = Charles Lenormand | architecture_type = Church | architecture_style = [[Romanesque Revival architecture|Romanesque Revival]] | general_contractor = | facade_direction = | groundbreaking = 1875 | year_completed = 1903 | construction_cost = | specifications = | capacity = | length = | width = | width_nave = | height_max = | dome_quantity = | dome_height_outer = | dome_height_inner = | dome_dia_outer = | dome_dia_inner = | minaret_quantity = | minaret_height = | spire_quantity = | spire_height = | materials = | nrhp = | added = | refnum = }} [[File:retablemonaco.jpg |thumb|''Altarpiece of St Nicolas - [[Ludovico Brea]], 1500'']] The '''Cathedral of Our Lady Immaculate''' (in [[French language]]: ''Cathédrale de Notre-Dame-Immaculée''), but sometimes called '''Saint Nicholas Cathedral''' (name of the old church which was demolished in 1874),{{cite web|url=http://www.wondermondo.com/Countries/E/Small/Monaco/MonacoCathedral.htm|title=Monaco Cathedral|publisher=Wondermondo}} '''Monaco Cathedral''' (French: ''Cathédrale de Monaco''), is the cathedral of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Monaco]] in [[Monaco-Ville]], [[Monaco]], where many of the [[House of Grimaldi|Grimaldis]] were buried, including [[Grace Kelly]] and—more recently—[[Rainier III, Prince of Monaco|Rainier III]]. The cathedral was built in 1875–1903 and consecrated in 1911, and is on the site of the first parish church in Monaco built in 1252 and dedicated to Saint Nicholas. Of note are the [[retable]] (circa 1500) to the right of the transept, the Great Altar and the Episcopal throne in white [[Carrara marble]]. Pontifical services take place on the major religious festivals, such as the Feast of [[Devota|Sainte Dévote]] (27 January) and the national holiday (19 November). On feast days and during religious music concerts, one can hear the magnificent four-keyboard organ, inaugurated in 1976. From September through June, “Les Petits Chanteurs de Monaco” and the singers of the Cathedral Choir School sing during Mass every Sunday at 10:00am. Mass is also celebrated here each year on 6 December, when primary children gather for a joyful remembrance of St. Nicholas' life. ==See also== *[[:Category:Burials at the Cathedral of Our Lady Immaculate, Monaco]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|Cathedral of Our Lady Immaculate, Monaco}} *{{Official website|https://diocese.mc/fr/paroisse/Cathédrale/}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1875 establishments in Monaco]] [[Category:Monaco-Ville]] [[Category:Roman Catholic cathedrals in Monaco]] [[Category:Roman Catholic cathedrals in Europe]] {{Europe-RC-cathedral-stub}} {{monaco-church-stub}}

{{one source|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox Political party |colorcode = red | name = Centre Party '86 |native_name = Centrumpartij '86 |logo = Logo of Centre Party '86.jpg |logo_size = 200px |chairman = Wim Wijngaarden
(1986-1994)
Henk Ruitenberg
(1994-1998) |foundation = 1986 |dissolution = 1998 |ideology = [[Ultranationalism]] |position = [[Far-right]] |split = [[Centre Party (Netherlands)]] |membership = |youth_wing = |international = |european = |colours = |headquarters = |newspaper = |website = |country = the Netherlands }} The '''Centre Party '86''', ([[Dutch language|Dutch]]: ''Centrumpartij '86''; abbr. '''CP’86'''), was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[far-right]] political party which existed between 1986 and 1998. The party was a more radical splinter from the [[Centre Party (Netherlands)|Centre Party]] and was established on 20 May 1986 and was disestablished on 18 November 1998, before an [[Amsterdam]] court ruled the party to be illegal. The [[New National Party (Netherlands)|NNP]] split off from the CP'86 in turn, several key people of that party had been prominent CP'86 members. ==External links== *[http://dnpp.eldoc.ub.rug.nl/FILES/root/publicatieLucardie/right-wing/rightextrem00.pdf Right-Wing Extremism in the Netherlands: Why it is still a marginal phenomenon] Dr. Paul Lucardie, DNPP ([[University of Groningen|RUG]]), November 2000 {{Historical Dutch political parties}} {{White Nationalism}} [[Category:Defunct political parties in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Far-right politics in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1986]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1998]] [[Category:1986 establishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:White nationalism in Europe]] {{netherlands-stub}}

{{Infobox film | name = Friday Night | image = | image size = | alt = | caption = | director = [[Danijel Sraka]] | producer = [[Ales Blatnik]]
Danijel Sraka | writer = [[Beno 'Stef' Torkar]] | narrator = | starring = [[Primoz Rokavc]]
[[Katarina Čas]]
[[Tadej Cepeljnik]]
[[Primoz Preksavec]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = [[Morena Fortuna]] | studio = | distributor = | released = {{start date|2000|3|31|df=y}} | runtime = 89 minutes | country = [[Slovenia]] | language = | budget = | gross = | preceded by = | followed by = }} '''''Friday Night'''''{{cite web|url=http://www.film-center.si/index.php?module=fdb&op=film&filmID=2288|title=Slovenian Film Center, Friday Night}} ({{lang-sl|V petek zvečer}}) is a Slovenian low-budget film that premiered in theaters across [[Slovenia]] in 2000. Directed by [[Danijel Sraka]]; written by [[Beno 'Stef' Torkar]]; produced by [[Ales Blatnik]] and Danijel Sraka. The film received extensive media coverage in Slovenia during filming as a result of being privately financed and having an international crew when most films from the area where dependent on state funds and local workers. The crew members brought in from abroad where [[Mikael Karlmark]] from Sweden, [[Roy Kurtluyan]] from [[Turkey]]/United States, [[Donald L. Painchaud]] from Canada and [[James Debbs]] from the United States. ==Summary== High school friends Edi, Marko, Katja, Mateja, and Petra are trying to find their way to graduation. Along the way they encounter extremely hostile teachers, offensive policemen, insane parents, and at one point aliens (?!). Will they succeed in reaching their goal: the ultimate 'be here or die' party? ==Film information== ===Cast=== * [[Primož Rokavc]] * [[Katarina Čas]] * [[Tadej Cepeljnik]] * [[Primož Preksavec]] * [[Tina Cvek]] * [[Manja Plesnar]] * [[Mateja Dominko]] * [[Ales Drolc]] * [[Jernej Kuntner]] * [[Jasna Kuljaj]] * [[Vesna Strehar]] * [[Matej Kralj]] * [[Polona Fabic]] * [[Mladen Bucic]] * [[Roman Zun]] * [[Zoran Smiljanic]] * [[Max Modic]] * [[Drago Razborsek]] * [[Breda Omerza]] * [[Danijel Smon]] * [[Jože Vunsek]] * [[Sonja Pantar]] * [[Andrija Hevka]] * [[Bostjan Regulj]] * [[Marcel Stefancic]] * [[Simona Habic]] * [[Jozef Jarh]] * [[Tomaž Cedilnik]] ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0287085|title=V petek zvecer}} * [http://www.megaklik.si/petek/ Official website] ==Notes== {{reflist}} [[Category:2000 films]] [[Category:2000s comedy films]] [[Category:Slovenian films]] [[Category:Slovene-language films]] [[Category:Films set in Slovenia]] [[Category:2000s teen films]] {{Slovenia-film-stub}} {{2000s-comedy-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=February 2013}} {{For|the similarly numbered formation in [[World War I]] and [[World War II]]|2nd Army Corps (France)}} {{Infobox Military Unit |unit_name=II Corps (Grande Armée) |image=2ndcorps augsburg.jpg |caption= The II Corps at Augsburg during the [[Ulm Campaign]] |dates=1805–1815 |country={{flagicon|France}} [[First French Empire]] |branch=Army |type=[[Army Corps]] |size=Two to four infantry divisions |battles=[[Napoleonic Wars]] |notable_commanders=[[Auguste de Marmont]]
[[Jean-Baptiste Bessières]]
[[Nicolas Soult]]
[[Nicolas Oudinot]]
[[Jean Lannes]]
[[Jean Reynier]]
[[Claude Perrin Victor]]
[[Honoré Charles Reille]] }} {{Grand Armee Corps}} The '''II Corps''' of the [[Grande Armée]] was a military unit that existed during the [[Napoleonic Wars]]. ==The Campaigns== At its formation in 1805, [[Auguste de Marmont]] was appointed commander of the corps. ===The War Of The Third Coalition=== It participated in the [[Ulm Campaign]] before advancing southeast to serve as a flank guard. Still under Marmont, the troops then served as the garrison of the [[Illyrian Provinces]] until 1809 when they became the ''Army of Dalmatia'' and later the [[XI Corps (Grande Armée)|XI Corps]]. ===The Peninsular War=== A new II Corps was created in 1808 in northern Spain from the troops under [[Marshal of France|Marshal]] [[Jean-Baptiste Bessières]]. Soon after, Marshal [[Nicolas Soult]] took command of the formation. In 1810, [[Jean Reynier]] assumed command of the corps in Spain until 1811 when the unit was suppressed. ===The War Of The Fifth Coalition=== Meanwhile, a parallel II Corps was created in 1809 to fight against Austria. The formation was led first by [[Nicolas Oudinot]], then by Marshal [[Jean Lannes]] who was fatally wounded at [[Battle of Aspern-Essling|Aspern-Essling]]. Oudinot took over the corps again and won his marshal's baton at [[Battle of Wagram|Wagram]] in July 1809. ===The Invasion Of Russia=== Still commanded by [[Marshal of France|Marshal]] [[Nicolas Oudinot]], the Corps took part in the [[French invasion of Russia (1812)|1812 invasion of Russia]], at which point its size was roughly 40,000 men. '''6th Division''' (Legrand) * [[Joseph Jean-Baptiste Albert]] Brigade ** 26th Light Infantry Regiment (four battalions) * Moreau Brigade ** 56th Line Infantry Regiment (four battalions) * [[Nicolas Joseph Maison]] Brigade ** 19th Line Infantry Regiment (four battalions) * Pamplona Brigade ** 128th Line Infantry Regiment (two battalions) ** 3rd Portuguese Regiment (two battalions) '''8th Division''' [[Jean-Antoine Verdier]] * Raymond-Vivies Brigade ** 11th Light Infantry Regiment (four battalions) ** 2nd Line Infantry Regiment (five battalions) * Pouget Brigade ** 37th Line Infantry Regiment (four battalions) ** 124th Line Infantry Regiment (three battalions) '''9th Division''' (Swiss) [[Pierre Hugues Victoire Merle]] * [[François Pierre Joseph Amey]] Brigade ** 4th Swiss Regiment (three battalions) ** 3rd Provisional Croatian Regiment (two battalions) * Condras Brigade ** 1st Swiss Regiment (two battalions) ** 2nd Swiss Regiment (three battalions) * Coustard Brigade ** 3rd Swiss Regiment (three battalions) ** 123rd Line Infantry Regiment (four battalions) '''Corps Cavalry''' * [[Bertrand Pierre Castex]] Brigade ** 23rd Chasseurs à Cheval Regiment (four squadrons) ** 24th Chasseurs à Cheval Regiment (four squadrons) * [[Jean-Baptiste Juvénal Corbineau]] Brigade ** 7th Chasseurs à Cheval Regiment (four squadrons) ** 20th Chasseurs à Cheval Regiment (four squadrons) ** 8th Chevau-Légers-Lanciers (four squadrons) ''Sources:'' ''Les effectifs de la Grande-armée pour la campagne de Russe de 1812'' - Paris 1913 ''Adjutant's Call'' of the Military Historical Society Vol. III - U.S.A. ===The War Of The Sixth Coalition=== The corps was reorganized in Germany in 1813 and Marshal [[Claude Perrin Victor]] was appointed to lead it. ===The War Of The Seventh Coalition=== The corps was headed by [[Honoré Charles Reille]] in 1815 and fought at [[Battle of Waterloo|Waterloo]]. {{DEFAULTSORT:II Corps (Grande Armee)}} [[Category:Corps of France in the Napoleonic Wars|GAI02]] {{France-stub}} {{Europe-mil-stub}}
