revision.text:
{{Africandiaspora-stub}}
The '''Institute of the Black World''' ('''IBW''') was a [[think tank]] based in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], which was founded and directed by [[African diaspora]] [[intellectual]]s from 1969 to 1983.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Johnson |first=Christopher K. |editors= Molefi Kete Asante and Ama Mazama|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Black Studies |date= |year= 2005|publisher= |location= |id= |doi= 10.4135/9781412952538.n141|chapter=Institute of the Black World |title=Encyclopedia of Black Studies |isbn=9780761927624 }}</ref> Led primarily by [[Vincent Harding]], it was originally a project of the [[Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change]]<ref>Soyer, Daniel, [http://www.encyclopedia.com/article-1G2-3444700638/institute-black-world.html "Institute of the Black World"], ''Encyclopedia of African-American Culture and History'', 2006.</ref> and is described by the historian Derrick E. White as "a collection of activist-intellectuals who analyzed the educational, political, and activist landscape to further the Black Freedom Struggle in the wake of King’s assassination."<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = University Press of Florida| isbn = 978-0-8130-4062-2| last = White| first = Derrick E| title =Challenge of Blackness: The Institute of the Black World and Political Activism in the 1970s| location = Gainesville| accessdate = 2016-09-21| date = 2011| url = http://public.eblib.com/choice/publicfullrecord.aspx?p=767222| page=2}}</ref> In addition to Harding, [[Stephen Henderson (literary scholar)|Stephen Henderson]] and William Strickland (of the University of Massachusetts) formed the core leadership in the early years of the IBW.<ref>White 2011:9.</ref><ref>[http://www.sacramentoblackbookfair.com/featured/bill_strickland.php Bill Strickland biography], Sacramento Black Book Fair.</ref>
The IBW sought to build connections across a range of diverse Black approaches, including [[Black nationalism]], [[Racial integration|integrationism]], and [[Marxism]], and in particular sought to reach three specific audiences: First, Black scholars developing Black Studies programs; second, Black elected officials; and third, grassroots organizations.<ref>White 2011:6.</ref> Its participants included nationalists [[John Henrik Clark]] and [[Julius Lester]], integrationists such as [[C. T. Vivian]], and a significant number of intellectuals from outside of the United States, particularly the Caribbean, including Marxist theorist [[C. L. R. James]], cultural theorist [[Sylvia Wynter]], historians [[Robert A. Hill (Jamaican historian)|Robert A. Hill]] and [[Walter Rodney]], and economists [[George Beckford]] and [[Norman Girvan]].<ref>White 2011:7.</ref>
The IBW's own orientation has been described as "pragmatic Black nationalism... rooted in specific issues such as Black Studies or the creation of a black political agenda for the seventies; thus, its pragmatism critically engaged and employed the best practices from a variety of ideological perspectives, including cultural and political nationalism, as well as integration."<ref>White 2011:8.</ref>
The organization closed in 1983.
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Organizations established in 1969]] [[Category:Organizations based in Atlanta]]

page.title: International Confederation for Disarmament and Peace

revision.comment: archives
revision.text:
The '''International Confederation for Disarmament and Peace''' was an organisation formed by peace groups from western and [[Non-Aligned Movement|non-aligned]] nations in 1963.
As a result of confrontation between western and Soviet delegates at the 1962 World Congress for Peace and Disarmament, which was organised by the [[USSR]]-backed [[World Peace Council]], non-aligned peace organisations decided to form an international body that would be independent of the World Peace Council. The founding conference of this body was attended by delegates from forty organizations.<ref name=radioradicale>[http://www.radioradicale.it/exagora/the-oxford-conference-of-non-aligned-peace-organizations Oxford Conference of Non-aligned Peace Organizations]</ref>
The founding organizations were:
*[[Accra Assembly Continuing Committee]] *[[Aktionsgruppen Mot Svensk Atoombomb]] *[[American Friends Service Committee]] *[[Arbeitsgemeinschaft Deutscher Friendensverbande]] *[[Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament]] (UK) *[[Canadian Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament]] *[[Colleges and Universities CND]] (UK) *[[Combined CND Groups and New South Wales and Queensland Peace Committee]] *[[Combined Universities Campaign]] (Canada) *[[Comite 1962 voor de Vrede]] *[[Committee of 100 (United Kingdom)]] *[[Committee for Non-Violent Action|Committee on Non-Violent Action]] *[[Consulta della Pace]] *[[European Federation Against Nuclear Arms]] *[[Fellowship of Reconciliation and War Resisters]] (Belgium) *[[Friends Peace Committee]] (UK) *[[Gandhi Peace Foundation]] *[[Greek Peace Committee]] *[[International Fellowship of Reconciliation]] *[[International Liaison Committee of Organizations for Peace]] *[[Irish CND]] *[[Kampagnen mod Atomvaben]] *[[Kampanjen mot Atomvapen]] *[[Komiteen for Oplysning om Atomfaren]] *[[National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy]] *[[National Peace Council]] (UK) *[[New Zealand CND]] *[[P.S.U]] (France) *[[Peace Pledge Union]] *Schweizerische Bewegung Gegen Die Altomare Anfrustung *[[Society for Social Responsibility in Science]] *[[Student Peace Union]] *[[Turn Towards Peace]] *[[Voice of Women]] (Canada) *[[War Resisters International]] *[[War Resisters League]] *[[Women’s International League for Peace and Freedom]] *[[Women Strike for Peace]] *[[Yugoslav League for Peace Independence and Equality of Peoples]].
It was merged with the [[International Peace Bureau]] in 1978.<ref>[http://www.iisg.nl/archives/en/files/i/10751811.php International Institute for Social History]</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
[[File:IUF logo.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Internet Ungovernance Forum]] {{Internet |expanded=Governance}}
The '''Internet Ungovernance Forum''' ('''IUF''') is an open forum for dialogue on issues of Internet censorship, freedom of speech, surveillance, privacy and community-centric governance approaches conceived by the [[Alternative Informatics Association]].<ref name=IUF2014>[https://iuf.alternatifbilisim.org/ "2014 Turkey - Internet Ungovernance Forum, official website"] Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref> The first Forum was held in Turkey in September, 2014 and served as model for the organization of the Brazilian and Italian Forums of 2015.
==History and development of the IUF==
=== IUF Turkey 2014 === The first '''Internet Ungovernance Forum''' was held in September 2014 in Turkey to demand that fundamental freedoms, openness, unity and net neutrality remain as the building blocks of the Internet. It was held in parallel to the [[Internet Governance Forum]] (IGF), which was already taking place in Istanbul between 2–5 September 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2014/09/07/internet-issues-discussed-in-internet-ungovernance-forum|title=Internet issues discussed in Internet Ungovernance Forum|last=|first=|date=2014-09-07|work=|newspaper=DailySabah|access-date=2017-02-02|via=}}</ref>
Earlier that year, access to [[Censorship of YouTube#Turkey|YouTube]] <ref name=YTblocked>[https://en.rsf.org/turkey-youtube-blocked-as-cyber-27-03-2014,46050.html "YouTube blocked as cyber-censorship mounts in run-up to election"] Reporters Without Borders. Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref> and [[Censorship of Twitter#Turkey|Twitter]] had been blocked in Turkey.<ref name=Twitterblocked>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-26677134 "Internet Ungovernance Forum Turkey 2014"] Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref>
Issues of internet censorship,<ref name=TDZ>[http://www.todayszaman.com/anasayfa_internet-censorship-reaching-dangerous-levels-in-turkey_393727.html "Internet censorship reaching dangerous levels in Turkey"] Today's Zaman. Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref> “preventive” website blocking orders without court's permission,<ref name=RSF>[http://blogs.rsf.org/en/2014/09/05/bye-bye-internet-freedom/ "Bye-Bye Internet Freedom"] Reporters Without Borders. Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref> surveillance <ref name=RSFB>[http://blogs.rsf.org/en/2014/09/05/turkey-smile-youre-being-watched/ "Turkey – smile, you’re being watched"] Reporters Without Borders. Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref> and privacy <ref name=GRD>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/06/turkey-internet-law-censorship-democracy-threat-opposition "Turkey pushes through new raft of 'draconian' internet restrictions"] The Guardian. Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref> in Turkey raised concerns among activists, and they started organizing the forum. They felt that issues such as [[Net neutrality]], [[Internet privacy]] and Freedom of Speech were not getting the right attention at IGF.<ref name="IUF2014"/>
Participants of the two-day conference included [[Julian Assange]], [[Jacob Appelbaum]] and [[Amelia Andersdotter]].
=== IUF Brazil 2015 === Because IGF fails to address issues such as: the controversies of the Brazilian Civil Rights Framework for the Internet;<ref name=piratetm>[http://piratetimes.net/new-brazilian-law-strips-citizens-rights/ "New Brazilian Law Strips Citizen’s Rights"] Pirate Times. Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref><ref name=spkd>[http://www.spiked-online.com/newsite/article/brazil-not-the-web-we-want/14888 "Brazil: Not the Web We Want"] Spiked-online. Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref> the fact that since 2013 law enforcement from Brazil has been acquiring surveillance devices from [[Hacking Team#2015 data breach|"Hacking Team"]] to be used against activists; the recent Brazilian laws institutionalizing mass surveillance<ref name=pls494>[http://www25.senado.leg.br/web/atividade/materias/-/materia/88862 "PROJETO DE LEI DO SENADO nº 494, de 2008"] Senado Federal. Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref> and data retention of all of its citizens;<ref name=pl1879>[http://www.camara.gov.br/proposicoesWeb/fichadetramitacao?idProposicao=1306687 "Projeto de Lei n. 1879/2015"] Câmara Federal. Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref> the congressional attempts to increase custody of massive logs and data to all the population and the ongoing process of criminalizing as terrorism any kind of hacktivism,<ref name=plc101>[http://www25.senado.leg.br/web/atividade/materias/-/materia/122772 "PROJETO DE LEI DA CÂMARA nº 101, de 2015"] Senado Federal. Retrieved 30 October 2015.</ref> Brazilian activists decided to organize their own forum in November 2015, parallel to the IGF that was going to be held in Joao Pessoa, Brazil.
=== IUF Italy 2015 ===
IUF Italy was held in Rome on November 7, 2015. Speakers included [[Digital_rights#Internet_Bill_of_Rights| Internet Bill of Rights]] commissioner [[Stefano Rodotà]] and [[ICANN]] representative Stefania Milan.
==External links== *[https://iuf.alternatifbilisim.org/ 2014 Turkey - Internet Ungovernance Forum], official website *[http://iuf.partidopirata.org/en/ 2015 Brazil - Internet Ungovernance Forum], official website *[http://iufitalia.net/ 2015 Italy - Internet Ungovernance Forum], official website
==References== {{reflist |30em}}

This is a '''list of Antarctic women'''. It includes explorers, researchers, educators, administrators and adventurers. They are arranged by the country of their latest citizenship rather than by country of birth.
{{TOC right}}
==Argentina== *[[Viviana Alder]] (born 1957), marine microbiologist *[[Irene Bernasconi]] (1896–1989), echinoderm specialist, member of the first team of Argentine scientists to work on Antarctica in 1968 *[[Patricia Ortúzar]] (graduated 2001), geographer, writer *[[Carmen Pujals]] (1916–2003), botanist, member of the first team of Argentine scientists to work on Antarctica in 1968 *[[Irene Schloss]] (PhD 1997), plankton biologist
==Australia== *[[Nerilie Abram]] (born 1977), climate change environmentalist *[[Leanne Armand]] (born 1968), marine scientist, diatom ecologist *[[Dana Bergstrom]] (born 1962), ecologist, biosecurity specialist, writer *[[Hope Black]] (born 1919), marine biologist, educator, early sub-Antarctic researcher *[[Elizabeth Chipman]] (born 1934), writer, one of the first Australian women to set foot on the Antarctic mainland in 1975 *[[Louise Crossley]] (1942–2015), South-African born environmentalist, station leader *[[Amanda Davies (scientist)|Amanda Davies]], geographer *[[Gwen Fenton]] (PhD 1985), biologist, first woman to be chief scientist of the Australian Antarctic Division *[[Samantha Hall]] (born 1982), environmental researcher *[[Catherine King (scientist)|Catherine King]] (graduated 1992), environmentalist specializing in ecotoxicology research *[[Delphine Lannuzel]] (graduated 2001), Belgian-born biogeochemist, educator *[[Nel Law]] (1914–1990), artist, writer, first Australian woman to set foot in Antarctica in 1961 *[[Diana Patterson]] (born early 1950s), first woman to head an Australian Antarctic station *[[Sally Poncet]] (born 1954), biologist, ornithologist, explorer *[[Patricia Margaret Selkirk]] (born 1942), plant biologist, ecologist *[[Justine Shaw]] (graduated 1996), ecologist, conservation scientist *[[Jan Strugnell]] (born 1976), evolutionary molecular biologist *[[Elizabeth Truswell]] (born 1941), palynologist, visual artist *[[Miriam-Rose Ungunmerr-Baumann]] (born 1950), one of the first two indigenous Australians to visit Antarctica *[[Barbara Wienecke]] (PhD 1993), Namibian-born seabird ecologist *[[Nerida Wilson]] (graduated 1998), invertebrate marine biologist
==Belgium== *[[Annick Wilmotte]] (graduated 1982), microbiologist
==Brazil== *[[Edith Fanta]] (1943–2008), biologist, Antarctic fish researcher *[[Vivian Pellizari]] (graduated 1992), microbiologist *[[Jane Schneider Pereyron Mocellin]] (Ph.D.,Geography and Psychology of Extreme Environments, thesis: A Behavioural Study of Human Responses to the Arctic and Antarctic Environments by Jane Schneider Pereyron Mocellin, University of British Columbia, 1988; M.A. in Geography, thesis: Human Adaptation to Living in Antarctic by Jane Schneider Pereyron Mocellin, University of Toronto, 1984)

==Chile== *[[Veronica Vallejos]] (born late 1960s), marine biologist, conservationist

==Trinidad and Tobago== *[[Marilyn Raphael]] (PhD 1990), climatologist, educator, writer
==Ukraine== *[[Halyna Kolotnytska]] (born 1972), cook of The Second Ukrainian Antarctic Expedition 1997/98 *[[Svitlana Krakovska]] (PhD 2003), meteorologist of The Second Ukrainian Antarctic Expedition 1997/98 *[[Liudmyla Mankovska]] (graduated 1970), meteorologist of The Second Ukrainian Antarctic Expedition 1997/98 *[[Maryna Orlova]] (PhD 1995), geophysicist of The Second Ukrainian Antarctic Expedition 1997/98
==United Kingdom== *[[Louise Allcock]] (graduated 1992), marine biologist, editor *[[Felicity Aston]] (born 1977), explorer, climate scientist *[[Kim Crosbie]] (born c.1969), environmentalist, citizen scientist, writer *[[Ginny Fiennes]] (1947–2004), explorer, her Transglobe Expedition team was the first to reach the two poles *[[Jane Francis]] (born 1956), palaeoclimatologist, director of the British Antarctic Survey *[[Helen Fricker]] (graduated 1991), glaciologist, writer *[[Karen Heywood]] (graduated 1983), oceanographer, educator *[[Eleanor Honnywill]] (c.1919–2003), contributor to the British Antarctic Survey, writer *[[Joanne Johnson]] (born 1977), geologist, writer *[[Jennifer Lee (scientist)|Jennifer Lee]], specialist in invasion biology *[[Hannah McKeand]] (born 1973) beat the record for solo skiing from the coast to the pole, 39 days. Beat the record for number of South Pole expeditions. *[[Tavi Murray]] (PhD 1990), glaciologist *[[Elizabeth Morris]] (born 1946), glaciologist *[[Pom Oliver]] (born 1952), explorer, film producer *[[Sharon Robinson (scientist)|Sharon Robinson]] (born 1961), plant physiologist, climate change biologist *[[Jane Rumble]], head of the Polar Regions Department, Foreign and Commonwealth Office, since 2007 *[[Rosie Stancer]] (born 1960), explorer, adventurer *[[Janet Thomson]] (born 1942), geologist, first British woman to undertake field research in Antarctica *[[Fiona Thornewill]] (born 1966), explorer *[[Jemma Wadham]] (PhD 1998), glacial biogeochemist
==United States== *[[Ann Bancroft]] (born 1955), writer, educator, adventurer, first woman to complete Arctic and Antarctic expeditions *[[Jenny Baeseman]] (graduated 1998), civil engineer, environmentalist, geoscientist *[[Robin Bell (scientist)|Robin Bell]] (graduated 1980), polar ice specialist *[[Mary Odile Cahoon]] (1929–2011), Benedictine nun, early Antarctic biological researcher *[[Kelly Falkner]] (born 1960), chemical oceanographer, educator *[[Patricia Hepinstall]], flight attendant, one of the first two women to fly to Antarctica in October 1957 *[[Barbara Hillary (adventurer)|Barbara Hillary]] (born 1931), first African-American woman to reach both poles *[[Louise Huffman]] (born 1951), educator specializing in polar science *[[Christina Hulbe]] (MSc 1994), geologist, educator *[[Lois Jones (scientist)|Lois Jones]] (1935–2000), geochemist, led the first all-woman science team to Antarctica in 1969 *[[Kelly Jemison]], geologist specializing in Antarctic diatoms *[[Ruth Kelley (flight attendant)|Ruth Kelley]], flight attendant, one of the first two women to fly to Antarctica in October 1957 *[[Amy Leventer]] (graduated 1982), marine biologist, micropaleontologist *[[Diane McKnight]] (born 1953), environmental engineer, educator, editor *[[Mary Alice McWhinnie]] (1922–1980), biologist, first American woman to head an Antarctic research station *[[Jill Mikucki]] (graduated 1996), microbiologist *[[Robyn Millan]] (graduated 1995), astronomist, physicist, investigating radiation belts *[[Tori Murden]] (born 1963), explorer, first woman to reach the South Pole by land in 1989 *[[Alison Murray (scientist)|Alison Murray]] (graduated 1989), microbiologist *[[Jerri Nielsen]] (1952–2009), physician, writer *[[Julie Palais]] (graduated 1974), glaciologist *[[Irene C. Peden]] (born 1925), electrical engineer, first American scientist to work in the Antarctic interior in 1970 *[[Ann Peoples (Antarctic manager)|Ann Peoples]] (graduated 1979), first American woman to have a management position in Antarctica *[[Erin Pettit]] (born 1971), glaciologist *[[Vanessa O'Brien]] (born 1964), mountain climber, explorer *[[Christina Riesselman]] (graduated 2001), paleoceanographer *[[Michelle Rogan-Finnemore]] (graduated 1981), scientist, legal expert *[[Jackie Ronne]] (1919–2009), explorer, first woman to be a working member of an Antarctic exhibition (1947–48) *[[Christine Siddoway]] (born 1961), structural geologist *[[Deborah Steinberg]] (graduated 1987), oceanographer, zooplankton ecologist *[[Cristina Takacs-Vesbach]] (born 1968), microbial ecologist *[[Lynne Talley]] (born 1954), physical oceanographer *[[Trista Vick-Majors]] (graduated early 2000s), microbial ecologist *[[Diana Wall]] (PhD in 1971), environmental scientist and a soil ecologist *[[Sophie Warny]] (born 1969), Belgian-born palynologist *[[Terry Wilson (scientist)|Terry Wilson]] (born 1954), geologist, tectonics specialist *Margaret Winslow (born 1949) geologist, tectonics specialist

[[File:Sinking Cap Trafalgar.jpg|thumb|300px|{{RMS|Carmania|1905|6}} sinking {{SMS|Cap Trafalgar||6}} near the Brazilian islands of [[Trindade and Martim Vaz|Trindade]], 14 September 1914.]] '''Merchant raiders''' are armed [[commerce raiding]] [[ship]]s that disguise themselves as [[non-combatant]] [[merchant vessel]]s.
==History== [[Germany]] used several merchant raiders early in [[World War I]] (1914–1918), and again early in [[World War II]] (1939–1945). The most famous{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} captain of a German merchant raider, [[Felix von Luckner]], used the sailing ship [[SMS Seeadler (Windjammer)|SMS ''Seeadler'']] for his voyage (1916–1917). The Germans used a sailing ship at this stage of the war because coal-fired ships had limited access to fuel outside of territories held by the [[Central Powers]] due to international regulations concerning refueling of combat ships in neutral countries.
Germany sent out two waves of six surface raiders each during [[World War II]]. Most of these vessels were in the {{convert|8000|–|10000|LT|t}} range. Many of these vessels had originally been [[refrigerator ship]]s, used to transport fresh food from the tropics. These vessels were faster than regular [[merchant vessel]]s, which was important for a [[warship]]. They were armed with six [[15 cm SK L/45|15cm]] (5.9 inch) [[naval gun]]s, some smaller guns, [[torpedo]]es, [[Reconnaissance aircraft|reconnaissance seaplanes]] and some were equipped for [[minelaying]]. Several captains demonstrated great creativity in disguising their vessels to masquerade as allied or as neutral merchants. ''[[German auxiliary cruiser Kormoran|Kormoran]]'' sank the Australian cruiser [[HMAS Sydney (D48)|''Sydney'']] in one of the most well-known episodes involving merchant raiders during World War II.
Italy intended to outfit four refrigerated [[Banana boat (ship)|banana boat]]s as merchant raiders during World War II (''[[Ramb I]]'', ''[[Ramb II]]'', ''[[Ramb III]]'' and ''[[Ramb IV]]''). Only ''Ramb I'' and ''Ramb II'' served as merchant raiders and neither ship sank enemy vessels. The New Zealand cruiser [[HMNZS Leander|''Leander'']] [[Action of 27 February 1941|sank ''Ramb I'']] off the Maldives (February 1941); ''Ramb II'' sailed to the Far East, where the Japanese prevented her from raiding, ultimately took her over and converted her to an auxiliary transport ship. (''Ramb III'' served as a convoy escort and ''Ramb IV'' was converted for the Italian Royal Navy to a hospital ship.)
These commerce raiders carried no armour because their purpose was to attack merchantmen, not to engage warships. Also it would be difficult to fit armour to a civilian vessel. Eventually most were sunk or transferred to other duties.
The British deployed [[Armed Merchant Cruiser]]s in World War I and in World War II. Generally adapted from [[Ocean liner|passenger liner]]s, they were larger than the German merchant raiders.
During [[World War I]], the British [[Royal Navy]] deployed [[Q-ship]]s to combat German [[U-boat]]s. Q-ships were warships posing as merchant ships so as to lure U-boats to attack them; their mission of destroying enemy warships differed significantly from the raider objective of disrupting enemy trade.
==See also== * [[Armed merchantmen]] <!-- *[[Auxiliary cruiser]] (redirects to armed merchantman) --> * [[German auxiliary cruiser Atlantis|Auxiliary cruiser ''Atlantis'']] * [[German auxiliary cruiser Kormoran|Auxiliary cruiser ''Kormoran'']] * [[SMS Möwe (auxiliary cruiser)|Auxiliary cruiser ''Möwe'']] * [[SMS Wolf (auxiliary cruiser)|Auxiliary cruiser ''Wolf II'']] * [[List of Japanese auxiliary cruiser commerce raiders]] * [[Prize (law)]] - admiralty law concerning material captured * [[Q-ship]]
==External links== * [https://books.google.com/books?id=69kDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA14 ''Merchant Ships Convert Into War Raiders, Paint And False Structures Provide Disguises'' September 1941] article details how Merchant Raiders operate in wartime * [http://www.ahoy.tk-jk.net/MaraudersWW1/Wolf.html Marauders of the Sea, German Armed Merchant Raiders During World War 1, Wolf] * [http://www.ahoy.tk-jk.net/MaraudersWW1/Moewe.html Marauders of the Sea, German Armed Merchant Raiders During World War 1, Möwe] * [http://www.bismarck-class.dk/hilfskreuzer/hilfskreuzer_menu.html Hilfskreuzer]
{{Unreferenced|date=February 2008}}

{{Infobox government agency |agency_name = Minister of State for Relations with the Parliament |nativename = Ministër i Shtetit për Marrëdhëniet me Parlamentin |type = Department |logo = Ministër për Marrëdhëniet me Parlamentin.svg |logo_width = 200px |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = 2013 |preceding2 = |dissolved = 2017 |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Albania]] |headquarters = [[Tirana]] |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = [[Ermonela Felaj]] ''([[Socialist Party of Albania|PS]])'' |minister1_pfo = Minister of State for Relations with the Parliament |chief1_name = |chief1_position = |child1_agency = |website = {{URL|http://www.kryeministria.al/}} |footnotes = }} {{Politics of Albania}}
The '''Ministry of State for Relations with the Parliament''' ({{sq|Ministria e Shtetit për Marrëdhëniet me Parlamentin}}) was a department of the [[Council of Ministers (Albania)|Albanian Government]] responsible for handling communications with the Parliament.<ref>[http://appa.al/category/ministria-e-shteti-per-marredheniet-me-parlamentin Ministria e Shtetit për Marrëdhëniet me Parlamentin]</ref>
==Ministers== * Ilirian Celibashi * [[Ermonela Felaj]]

Armando Ribeiro
Marc-Olivier
Dani
Minh-Anh
Franco CasaGrande
Denis
Xavier Nussbaum |past_members = }} '''Moonraisers''' are a [[reggae]] band formed in 1992 and based in [[Neuchâtel]], [[Switzerland]]. Their style, a type of electronic reggae dubbed ''World’n’Moonstyle Reggae'', joins roots reggae with [[funk]], [[world music|world]] and [[electronica|electro]] elements.They are best known for composing the original version of the dance super hit, ''Rise up''. Although at the time it came out it didn't make any success, the song became a hit played in the dance clubs for months after Yves laRocke made a dance cover of it. == Discography == === Albums === * '''Mirror''' (''13 self produced songs, 1996'') : 1. Intro Nine Miles / 2. Get Up / 3. Joyless People / 4. Legal Destruction / 5. Right Way / 6. Mystic Dreams / 7. Surviving Children / 8. Make Change The World / 9. Rastaman Rebellation / 10. Moonrais Revolution / 11. Shining World / 12. No Want To Give Up / 13. Mirror / 14.Shamans Groove * '''World Without Wars''' (''5 self produced songs, 1997'') : 1. Let Peace Rule / 2. 1st May 2000 / 3. Reggae 2000 / 4. Guilty / 5. Make Change The World * '''Legacy''' (''14 songs produced by The Source Music Production, Pedi Sterchi and Moonraisers, 1999'') : 1. Dreams / 2. Thanks For All / 3. Not Afraid / 4. Hey World / 5. Time / 6. Four Crows / 7. New World / 8. Spirit Tango / 9. Music Evolution / 10. Can't Fly Too High / 11. Radja Ska / 12. Maconha / 13. Oh Child / 14. Hope Groove * '''Live''' (''9 self produced live songs, 2001'') : 1. Can't Fly Too High (Live) / 2. Guilty (Live) / 3. Hey World (Live) / 4. New World (Live) / 5. Not Afraid (Live) / 6. Peanuts (Live) / 7. Spirit Tango (Live) / 8. Train Of Bagdad (Live) / 9. 4 Crows (Live) * '''Human''' (''12 songs produced byr P.Brunkow, 2003'') : 1. Human / 2. 8 Giants / 3. Time Run / 4. Difference / 5. For Real / 6. Goes Around / 7. Congo Square / 8. Talking / 9. Slave Station / 10. So Much Trouble / 11. Who Can Prove It / 12. Full Moon * '''Do The Right Step''' (''15 songs produced by Damp Music, 2007'') : 1. Solidarity / 2. pPppet Master / 3. White Spliff / 4. Rise Up / 5. Funky Reggae Party / 6. Hotel California / 7. One God / 8. Rain A Fall / 9. To Those / 10. Why Take It / 11. Good Vibes / 12. $ Ship / 13. The Sun Shine For All / 14. Transition / 15. Intronisation === Singles === * '''Goes Around''' (''3 versions produced by P. Brunkow, 2003'') : 1. Goes Around / 2. Goes Around (P.Brunkow Remix) / 3. Goes Around (Extended P.Brunkow Remix) * '''Hotel California''' (''2 versions produced by Damp Music and Moonraisers, 2007'') : 1. Hotel California (Radio) / 2. Hotel California (Extendet) == References == {{Reflist}} Website of the Band: http://www.moonraisers.com {{Authority control}} [[Category:Swiss reggae musical groups]] {{Europe-band-stub}}

revision.text:
{{infobox military award | name = Nansen medal for Outstanding Research
''Nansenmedaljen for fremragende forskning'' | image = Nansenmedaljen for femragende forskning stripe.svg | caption = Ribbon bar of the medal | awarded_by = {{NOR}} | country = | type = | eligibility = Individuals | for = Scientists who have been awarded the Fridtjof Nansen prize for outstanding research | campaign = | status = | description = | motto = | clasps = | post-nominals = | established = 2003 | first_award = | last_award = | total = | posthumous = | recipients = | precedence_label = | individual = | higher = [[Medal for Rescue at Sea]] | same = | lower = [[Norwegian Police Cross of Honour]] | related = | image2 = | caption2 = }} The '''Nansen medal for Outstanding Research''' is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] medal awarded by the [[Nansen fund]]. The medal is awarded to scientists who have produced research of international significance of a very high level. The medal is awarded to Norwegian scientists or to scientists residing permanently in Norway. The medal is awarded to recipients of the [[Fridtjof Nansen prize for outstanding research]] since 2003 and was approved as an official Norwegian medal by Royal Resolution on 25 April 2007. The Nansen Prize has been awarded since 1897 and in a ceremony in 2003 all living prizewinners were awarded the medal. Since 2003 the prize and the medal has been awarded in the same ceremony. The medal is ranked 15 in the ranking of [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Norway|orders, decorations and medals of Norway]]. ==Description of the Medal== * The medal is circular and silver. * The obverse shows the head of Fridtjof Nansen surrounded by the inscription FRIDTJOF NANSENS BELØNNING FOR FREMRAGENDE FORSKNING (Fridtjof Nansen's Award for Outstanding Research). * The reverse bears the inscription FRIDTJOF NANSENS FOND TIL VIDENSKABENS FREMME (Fridtjof Nansen's Fund to Promote Science) in a laurel wreath. * The ribbon is royal blue with white edge stripes. ==See also== * [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Norway]] ==References== *Overview of official Norwegian decorations in ''f-xtra'', nr. 1, 2009, appended to ''Forsvarets Forum'', nr. 11, 2009 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090220144019/http://www.nansenfondet.no/belonning.htm Fridtjof Nansen prize for outstanding research], The Nansen fund. {{DEFAULTSORT:Nansen medal for Outstanding Research}} [[Category:Civil awards and decorations of Norway]] [[Category:Recipients of the Nansen medal for Outstanding Research]] [[Category:Awards established in 2003]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Norway]] {{Norway-stub}} {{Award-stub}}

page.title: News Corporation takeover bid for BSkyB

revision.comment: /* References */
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=May 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} The '''News Corporation takeover bid for BSkyB''' was a proposed takeover of [[British Sky Broadcasting]] (BSkyB) by [[News Corporation]], the media conglomerate of [[Rupert Murdoch]]. The bid was launched in June 2010, but was withdrawn in July 2011 following the [[News International phone hacking scandal]]. News Corporation already owned 39.1% of BSkyB, and held on to its stake following the collapse of the takeover bid. The takeover was an essential part of News Corporation's business strategy, not least as it would have made possible integration with other entities such as [[Sky Deutschland]] and [[Sky Italia]].<ref name=Pratley>Nils Pratley, ''[[The Guardian]]'', 12 July 2011, [https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/jul/11/viewpoint-news-corp-bskyb-takeover News Corp needs all of BSkyB]</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' went so far as to say that, "Without a full takeover of BSkyB, News Corp's global satellite strategy would look an unco-ordinated mess."<ref name=Pratley/>
The first key turning point in the planned takeover was the removal in December 2010 of regulatory approval from [[Vince Cable]], who had told undercover reporters from ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' he had "declared war" on Murdoch. When these comments were made public, the final say on the deal went instead to [[Jeremy Hunt (politician)|Jeremy Hunt]]. Cable's comments on this matter were not published by the ''Telegraph'', but were instead leaked to BBC journalist [[Robert Peston]], most likely (according to a later Telegraph investigation) by two former Telegraph employees who had moved to [[News International]], a News Corporation subsidiary. Hunt was much more sympathetic to the takeover bid than Cable.
The second turning point was the series of revelations in early July of the hacking of the phones of non-celebrity victims by the ''[[News of the World]]'', a tabloid newspaper published by News International. Details of the activities, especially regarding the paper's hacking into the voicemail of murder victim [[Milly Dowler]], sparked widespread outrage against News Corporation. Attempts to defuse the scandal by closing the ''News of the World'' and publishing an apology by Murdoch both failed. In the face of a planned motion in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] calling on News Corporation to abandon the bid, News Corporation acquiesced.
==Offer== On 15 June 2010, BSkyB announced that it had rejected an offer from [[News Corporation]] to take full control of the company. News Corp had offered 700p per share for the remaining 60.9% of shares that it did not own. BSkyB said that it would only consider offers of at least 800p per share.<ref name="offereject">{{Cite news | title = BSkyB knocks back Murdoch takeover bid | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 15 June 2010 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2010/06/15/uk-bskyb-knocks-back-murdoch-takeover-bid/ | accessdate = 3 March 2011 }}</ref>
==Regulatory issues== Although the two companies had not agreed on a revised takeover proposal, News Corporation announced its intention to seek regulatory approval from the European Commission in November.<ref name="seekapproval">{{Cite news | title = News Corp. Seeks EU Antitrust Approval for Proposed BSkyB Deal | publisher=Bloomberg | date = 4 November 2010 | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-03/news-corp-seeks-european-union-antitrust-approval-for-proposed-bskyb-deal.html | accessdate = 3 March 2011 | first1=Jonathan | last1=Browning | first2=Erik | last2=Larson }}</ref> The Commission unconditionally approved the proposal the following month.<ref name="ecapproval">{{Cite news | title = EU clears Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation BSkyB bid | publisher=BBC News | date = 21 December 2010 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-12050296 | accessdate = 3 March 2011 }}</ref>
The proposal was also reviewed by the British government. On 4 November 2010 [[Secretary of State for Business, Innovation and Skills|Business Secretary]] [[Vince Cable]] referred the takeover bid to [[Ofcom]] to consider issues of media plurality.<ref name=timeline>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/phone-hacking/8634176/News-of-the-World-phone-hacking-scandal-timeline.html |title=News of the World phone hacking scandal: timeline |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=13 July 2011|accessdate=14 July 2011 |location=London |first1=Indu |last1=Chandrasekhar |first2=Murray |last2=Wardrop |first3=Andy |last3=Trotman}}</ref> In July 2011 it was reported that around this time News Corp's [[News International]] subsidiary had "bullied" the Liberal Democrats. ''[[The Observer]]'' said that "According to one account from a senior party figure, a cabinet minister was told that, if the government did not do as NI wanted, the Lib Dems would be 'done over' by the Murdoch papers."<ref>''[[The Observer]]'', 24 July 2011, [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/23/news-international-liberal-democrats-bskyb News International 'bullied Liberal Democrats over BSkyB bid']</ref>
In late December 2010, undercover reporters from ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', posing as constituents, set up a meeting with Cable, in which he made some unguarded remarks about the coalition, including a description of the coalition's attempt at fast, widespread reforms (including the health service and local governments) as being a "kind of Maoist revolution". When his comments appeared in the press on 21 December, Cable stated, "Naturally I am embarrassed by these comments and I regret them", before reaffirming his commitment to the coalition government, stating that "I am proud of what it is achieving".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/liberaldemocrats/8215462/Vince-Cable-I-could-bring-down-the-Government.html |title=Vince Cable: I could bring down the Government |work=The Daily Telegraph |date= 20 December 2010|accessdate=21 December 2010 |location=London |first=Holly |last=Watt}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Norman Smith |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-12045792 |title=Vince Cable said he could quit coalition if pushed |publisher=BBC |date= 21 December 2010|accessdate=21 December 2010}}</ref> In May 2011 the [[Press Complaints Commission]] upheld a complaint regarding the ''Telegraph'''s use of subterfuge: "On this occasion, the commission was not convinced that the public interest was such as to justify proportionately this level of subterfuge."<ref>''[[The Guardian]]'', 10 May 2011, [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/may/10/daily-telegraph-vince-cable-tapes Daily Telegraph censured by PCC over Vince Cable tapes]</ref>
In an undisclosed part of the ''Telegraph'' transcript, Cable stated in reference to [[Rupert Murdoch]]'s News Corporation takeover bid for BSkyB, "I have declared war on Mr Murdoch and I think we are going to win." This was given to the [[BBC]]'s [[Robert Peston]] by a whistleblower unhappy that the ''Telegraph'' had not published Cable's comments in full, and also published on 21 December.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-12053656 |title=Vince Cable criticises Murdoch takeover in secret tapes |publisher=BBC |date= 21 December 2010|accessdate=21 December 2010}}</ref> Following this revelation Cable had his responsibility for media affairs – including ruling on Murdoch's takeover plans – withdrawn from his role as business secretary that same day.<ref>Patrick Wintour, [https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/dec/21/vince-cable-war-murdoch-gaffe "Humiliated Vince Cable stripped of Sky role after 'war with Murdoch' gaffe"], ''The Guardian'', 21 December 2010. Retrieved 23 January 2011.</ref> In July 2011 a firm of private investigators hired by the ''Telegraph'' to track the source of the leak concluded "strong suspicion" that two former Telegraph employees who had moved to [[News International]], one of them [[William Lewis (journalist)|Will Lewis]], had gained access to the transcript and audio files and leaked them to Peston.<ref>''[[The Guardian]]'', 23 July 2011, [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jul/22/willlewis-telegraphmediagroup News Corp boss 'linked' to leak of Vince Cable's Rupert Murdoch comments]</ref>
After the business secretary Vince Cable was stripped of his jurisdiction over the deal, the proposal was referred to [[Jeremy Hunt (politician)|Jeremy Hunt]], the [[Secretary of State for Culture, Olympics, Media and Sport|Secretary of State for culture, media and sport]].<ref name="tohunt">{{Cite news | title = News Corp-Sky spotlight shifts to Hunt | work=The Spy Report | publisher=Media Spy | date = 23 December 2010 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2010/12/23/uk-news-corp-sky-spotlight-shifts-to-hunt/ | accessdate = 3 March 2011 }}</ref> Hunt initially elected not to refer to the deal to the [[Competition Commission]], announcing on 3 March 2011 that he intended to accept a series of undertakings given by News Corporation, paving the way for the deal to be approved. The undertakings would have led to [[Sky News]] being severed from BSkyB.<ref name="skyspinoff">{{Cite news | title = Hunt gives green light to News Corp-Sky deal | work= The Spy Report | publisher= Media Spy | date = 3 March 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/03/03/hunt-gives-green-light-to-news-corp-sky-deal/ | accessdate = 3 March 2011 }}</ref> On 23 June it was reported that News Corp had reached an agreement with [[Ofcom]] to approve the takeover, on the basis of [[Sky News]] becoming a separate company.<ref>''[[The Independent]]'', 23 June 2011, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/tv-radio/hunt-set-to-give-goahead-to-bskyb-deal-next-week-2301420.html Hunt set to give go-ahead to BSkyB deal next week]</ref>
By early July, despite public opposition to the deal, "Government says its ready to give clearance to deal. Jeremy Hunt gives opponents one final week to raise objections. However, he has provisionally agreed to proposals that will see Sky News be spun off as an independent company to allay fears the deal would give Mr Murdoch's News Corporation too much control of the media. After the consultation ends on July 8, Mr Hunt is expected to wave the merger through once and for all. He is keen to give final confirmation by July 19 when the summer parliamentary recess begins."<ref name=timeline/> Several days later, with the [[News of the World phone hacking scandal]] exploding, [[Ofcom]] intervened, saying that it has "a duty to be satisfied on an ongoing basis that the holder of a broadcasting licence is 'fit and proper'".<ref name=timeline/>
==Bid withdrawn== It was in the wake of the [[Milly Dowler]] phone hacking allegations that a significant number of people, including former deputy prime minister [[John Prescott]] and other politicians, began to seriously question whether the takeover of BSkyB by News Corporation ought to be blocked.<ref name="prescottcomment">{{Cite news | title = Milly Dowler phone hacking: Politicians hit out over revelations |author1=Mulholland, Hélène |author2=Robinson, James |lastauthoramp=yes | work=The Guardian | date = 4 July 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/jul/04/milly-dowler-phone-hacking-politicians | accessdate =5 July 2011 | location=London}}</ref> The [[Media Standards Trust]] formed the pressure group ''[[Media Standards Trust#Hacked Off|Hacked Off]],'' to campaign for a [[public inquiry]]. Soon after launch, the campaign gained the support of suspected hacking victim, the actor [[Hugh Grant]], who became a public spokesperson, appearing on ''[[Question Time (TV series)|Question Time]]'' and ''[[Newsnight]].''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mediastandardstrust.org/mst-news/hacked-off-campaign-for-a-public-inquiry-into-phone-hacking/|title=Media Standards Trust " Blog Archive " Hacked Off: Campaign for a Public Inquiry into Phone Hacking|publisher=mediastandardstrust.org|accessdate=20 January 2015}}</ref>
In July 2011, during the [[News International phone hacking scandal]], BSkyB shares plummeted<ref>{{cite web|last=Barr |first=Robert |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/07/08/2304932/bskyb-shares-down-again-as-pm.html |title=BSkyB shares plunge on News Corp bid doubts – National Business |work=The Miami Herald |accessdate=14 July 2011}}</ref> and Hunt received well over 150,000 submissions from members of the public, driven by efforts by campaign groups [[Avaaz.org]] and [[38 Degrees]]. Most submissions were opposed to News Corp taking full control of BSkyB. News Corp subsequently withdrew undertakings made as part of negotiations with the government, triggering an immediate referral of the proposal to the Competition Commission.<ref name="referralcomp">{{Cite news | title = BSkyB takeover proposal referred to Competition Commission | work= The Spy Report | publisher= Media Spy | date = 12 July 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/12/bskyb-takeover-proposal-referred-to-competition-commission/ | accessdate = 16 July 2011 }}</ref>
Numerous analysts and commentators suggested that as a result of the phone hacking scandal, it would be politically difficult or impossible for News Corp to proceed with its takeover plans.<ref name="sentiment1">{{Cite news | title = Hack job! Murdoch axes paper to save deal |author1=Holton, Kate |author2=Prodhan, Georgina | agency= Reuters | date = 7 July 2011 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/07/us-newscorp-hacking-idUSTRE7641IO20110707 | accessdate = 16 July 2011 }}</ref><ref name="sentiment2">{{Cite news | title = BSkyB's share price expectations reduced after scandal | work= Proactive Investors | date = 8 July 2011 | url = http://www.proactiveinvestors.co.uk/companies/news/30413/bskybs-share-price-expectations-reduced-after-scandal-30413.html | accessdate = 16 July 2011 }}</ref><ref name="sentiment3">{{Cite news | title = News Corp's BSkyB takeover bid at risk | publisher= Al Jazeera | date = 12 July 2011 | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/video/europe/2011/07/2011711151013224395.html | accessdate = 16 July 2011 }}</ref> In addition to public pressure for the deal to be withdrawn or for the Government to halt the proposal, Britain's major political parties all expressed the view that the deal should not go ahead. The [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] and the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservatives]] both indicated that they would support an [[opposition day]] motion from [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] calling on News Corp to rescind its offer.<ref name="parliamentmotion">{{Cite news | title = Withdraw the BSkyB proposal: Murdoch faces humiliation as Government backs Labour | work= The Spy Report | publisher= Media Spy | date = 13 July 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/13/withdraw-the-bskyb-proposal-murdoch-faces-humiliation-as-government-backs-labour/ | accessdate = 16 July 2011 }}</ref>
On 13 July, shortly before the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] was due to debate the motion, News Corporation announced that it would be withdrawing its proposal to take complete ownership of BSkyB.<ref name="BBC-withdraw">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-14142307|title=News Corp withdraws bid for BSkyB|publisher=BBC|date=13 July 2011|accessdate=13 July 2011}}</ref> Chase Carey, the corporation's deputy chairman, stated that it was "too difficult to progress" with the proposed takeover given the phone hacking controversy.<ref name="bskybpullout">{{Cite news | title = Facing overwhelming pressure, News Corp pulls out of bid for BSkyB | work = The Spy Report | publisher = Media Spy | date = 13 July 2011 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2011/07/13/facing-overwhelming-pressure-news-corp-pulls-out-of-bid-for-bskyb/ | accessdate = 16 July 2011 }}</ref>
In a symbolic gesture, the House later passed the opposition day motion unanimously by [[acclamation]].<ref name="bskybmotionvote">{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201011/cmhansrd/chan187.pdf |title=Parliamentary Debates (Hansard) |publisher=House of Commons |date=13 July 2011 |accessdate=16 July 2011}}</ref><ref name="bskybmotionreport">{{Cite news | title = Phone-hacking scandal + PMQs – Wednesday 13 July 2011 | author = Sparrow, Andrew | work = The Guardian | date = 13 July 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/blog/2011/jul/13/phone-hacking-scandal-live-coverage | accessdate = 16 July 2011 | location=London }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{2011 News Corporation scandal}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use British English|date=February 2016}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2011}} '''Nicky Horne''' was a road manager for [[Emperor Rosko]] in 1969, before presenting shows on [[BBC Radio 1]], from 1970 - 1973.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.somethingjewish.co.uk/articles/2515_radio_1_jews.htm |title=Radio 1 Jews |last=Westbrook |first=Caroline |date=30 September 2007 |publisher=somethingjewish.co.uk |accessdate=25 August 2011 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120409162721/http://www.somethingjewish.co.uk/articles/2515_radio_1_jews.htm |archivedate=9 April 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Horne was one of the original line-up on London's [[Capital London|Capital Radio]], where he presented shows such as ''Your Mother Wouldn't like it'', ''Mummy's Weekly'' & ''6 of the Best''. He remained on [[Capital London|Capital Radio]] until 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brandrepublic.com/news/464942/legendary-rock-dj-nicky-horne-return-capital-weekend-gold-show/|title=Legendary rock DJ Nicky Horne return to Capital with weekend Gold show|last=Matthews|first=Sam|date=9 March 2005|publisher=Brand Republic News|accessdate=25 August 2011}}</ref>
He covered [[American football]] with [[Miles Aiken]] in the 1980s.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_uQHZSObh08C&q=%22miles+aiken%22+basketball&dq=%22miles+aiken%22+basketball&hl=en&sa=X&ei=VgmsUa37CfSo4AP5tIGgBA&ved=0CEMQ6AEwAw |author=Julian Farino|title=Guinness Sports Challenge |publisher=Guinness |year=1987 |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Q8NAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=A6YMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4711,4847975&dq=miles-aiken&hl=en |title=. |publisher=The Glasgow Herald= |date= |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=William Taaffe |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1121487/index.htm |title=Sunday night NFL games on the telly are a merrie olde |publisher=Sports Illustrated |date=21 November 1983 |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref>
Since then, he re-joined [[BBC Radio 1|Radio 1]] in the early 1990s where he was a stand-in presenter and at the same time, he presented a weekend afternoon show on [[Classic FM (UK)|Classic FM]]. He also worked on the UK commercial radio overnight sustaining service, [[The Superstation]].
His TV career has included presenting American Football on Channel 4, ''Rock Steady'', and ''Earsay'' also on Channel 4, American Football, and NBA for Sky Sports, and for many years was the presenter of ATP tennis, and Davis Cup worldwide.
Horne joined [[Virgin Radio]] in 1995. He took over the drivetime show from the sacked [[Nick Abbot]] and 2 weekend shows as well. In 1997, he took on the weekday afternoon show from 1{{snd}}4{{nbsp}}pm, before leaving the station in 1998.
In 1998 Horne joined [[BBC Radio 2]], presenting the weekend overnight show (Fridays/Saturdays 12 midnight{{snd}}3{{nbsp}}am and Saturdays/Sundays 1{{snd}}4{{nbsp}}am), before his shows were taken over by [[Lynn Parsons]] in 1999.
At the beginning of 2003, Horne replaced [[Charles Nove]] on the drivetime show on London's [[102.2 Jazz FM|Jazz FM]], later moving to mid-mornings until mid-2005, From then on, he was heard on [[Gold (radio)|Capital Gold]] every Sunday afternoon fronting a ''Classic Album Show''. He worked at the digital radio station [[Planet Rock (radio station)|Planet Rock]] as the weekday evening presenter<ref>[http://planetrock.com/nicky-horne-667792|Nicky Horne's profile on the Planet Rock website]</ref> until 17 May 2013. He then left to join TeamRock Radio, starting as the evening presenter (6{{nbsp}}{{snd}}9{{nbsp}}pm) in June.<ref>[http://radiotoday.co.uk/2013/04/teamrock-hires-planet-rocks-nicky-horne/ Online article on trade website]</ref><ref>[https://twitter.com/NickyHorne/status/335689563957760000 Twitter update from Nicky]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Airline |airline = OKI Air Group |logo = OKI Air Logo.png |logo_size = 250 |fleet_size = |destinations = |IATA = |ICAO = |callsign = |parent = |company_slogan = |founded = 1993 |headquarters = [[Podgorica]], [[Montenegro]] |key_people = Orhan Hodžić |hubs = [[Podgorica Airport]] |secondary_hubs = |focus_cities = |frequent_flyer = |lounge = |alliance = |website = http://www.oki.me}} '''OKI Air International''' is an [[airline]] based in [[Podgorica]], [[Montenegro]]. It is a privately owned charter airline operating within Montenegro and the surrounding area. Its main base is [[Podgorica Airport]].<ref name="FI">{{cite news | title= Directory: World Airlines | work= [[Flight International]] | page= 58 | date= 2007-04-10}}</ref>
== History ==
The airline was established on 28 April 1993 and started operations in 1993 with flights from Podgorica to [[Bari]], [[Ljubljana]], [[Skopje]] and other destinations, as well as charter flights. It was the second airline company to be founded in Montenegro. It is owned by Jusuf Hodžić (50%) and Orhan Hodžić (50%) and has 15 employees (at March 2007).<ref name="FI"/>
== Fleet ==
As of January 2005 the OKI Air International fleet includes:<ref>[[Flight International]], 5–11 April 2005</ref>
== External links == *[http://www.oki.me Official Website]
== References == <references/>
